Hyderabad, being a hub of medical excellence, is home to some of the finest pulmonologists offering advanced treatments and personalized care.

sections.heading: Why Consult a Pulmonologist?
paragraphs: A pulmonologist specializes in diagnosing and managing a wide range of respiratory conditions, including:
list: Asthma: A chronic lung condition causing breathing difficulties due to airway inflammation and narrowing.
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD): A progressive disease that causes airflow obstruction in the lungs, making it difficult to breathe.
Tuberculosis (TB): A contagious bacterial infection that most often affects the lungs.
Lung Infections: Infections that affect the lungs, such as pneumonia and bronchitis.
Sleep Apnea: A sleep disorder that causes snoring, breathing interruptions during sleep.
Interstitial Lung Diseases (ILDs): A group of diseases that cause scarring of the lung tissue, making it difficult to breathe.
Pulmonary Hypertension: High blood pressure in the arteries that carry blood to the lungs, leading to breathing difficulties and heart strain.

sections.subheading: What to Expect During a Pulmonology Consultation?
paragraphs: A pulmonology consultation involves a comprehensive evaluation of your respiratory health. Here's what you can typically expect:
list: Medical History Assessment: The pulmonologist will ask detailed questions about your current symptoms (e.g., cough, shortness of breath, chest pain), past medical conditions, any medications you're taking, allergies, smoking history, and family history of respiratory illnesses. Be prepared to provide as much information as possible.

Physical Examination: The doctor will perform a physical exam, which may include listening to your lungs with a stethoscope, checking your oxygen levels with a pulse oximeter, and observing your breathing patterns.

paragraphs: Diagnostic Tests: Depending on your symptoms and medical history, the pulmonologist may order various tests, such as:
1.Pulmonary Function Tests (PFTs): These tests measure how well your lungs are working, including lung volume, airflow, and gas exchange.
list: 2. Chest X-ray: This imaging test can help visualize the structures in your chest, including your lungs, heart, and blood vessels.
3. CT Scan: A more detailed imaging test that can provide cross-sectional views of your lungs and other chest structures.
4. Blood Tests: These tests can help identify infections, inflammation, or other underlying conditions.

paragraphs: Other tests may be ordered as needed, such as bronchoscopy, sleep studies, or allergy testing.
Treatment Plan: Based on the results of your evaluation, the pulmonologist will develop a personalized treatment plan. This may include:
1.Medications: Such as inhalers, oral medications, or other therapies to manage your respiratory condition.
list: Lifestyle Changes: Recommendations for diet, exercise, smoking cessation, or avoiding environmental triggers.
Advanced Therapies: In some cases, more advanced treatments might be necessary, such as oxygen therapy, pulmonary rehabilitation, or even surgery.

paragraphs: The goal of the consultation is to accurately diagnose your respiratory condition and create an effective treatment plan to improve your breathing and overall quality of life. Don't hesitate to ask questions during your appointment to ensure you understand your condition and treatment options.

sections.subheading: How to Choose the Best Pulmonologist in Hyderabad?
paragraphs: When choosing a pulmonologist, consider their experience, specialization, hospital affiliation, patient reviews, and access to advanced facilities.

sections.heading: Preventive Measures for Better Lung Health
paragraphs: While seeking expert care is important, adopting a healthy lifestyle can significantly reduce the risk of respiratory diseases. Here are some key preventive tips:
list: No Smoking – Smoking is the leading cause of lung disease, including COPD and lung cancer.
Stay Active – Regular exercise strengthens the lungs and improves overall health.
Follow a Healthy Diet & Lifestyle – A diet rich in antioxidants & leading a healthy lifestyle supports lung health.
Practice Breathing Exercises – Techniques such as pranayama and deep breathing enhance lung function.
Avoid Air Pollution – Wear masks in high-pollution areas and ensure proper ventilation at home.

blogs.title: Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV): Symptoms, Treatment, and Impact on Adults and Children

paragraphs: Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV) symptoms , part of the Pneumoviridae family, is a respiratory virus responsible for illnesses ranging from mild colds to severe lung infections like pneumonia and bronchiolitis. Despite being less recognized than influenza or Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV), HMPV respiratory virus is a significant contributor to respiratory illnesses globally, particularly during winter and spring. Understanding its symptoms, treatment options, and preventive measures is crucial, especially for vulnerable groups such as children, older adults, pregnant women, and those with compromised immune systems.

sections.heading: High-Risk Groups for Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV)
paragraphs: Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV) respiratory virus does not discriminate in whom it affects, but its severity varies among different population groups:
list: Young Children: Infants and toddlers are highly susceptible to severe conditions like bronchiolitis and pneumonia due to their developing immune systems.
Older Adults: Those aged 65 or older, especially individuals with chronic respiratory conditions like asthma or COPD, face an elevated risk of severe symptoms.
Pregnant Women: Respiratory complications from HMPV can endanger both mother and baby.

paragraphs: Immunocompromised Individuals: Those with weakened immune systems, such as cancer patients or transplant recipients, are at higher risk of severe respiratory distress.

sections.subheading: Symptoms of Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV) in Adults and Children
paragraphs: Identifying Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV) symptoms early can help manage its effects and prevent complications.
In Adults:
list: Persistent cough with mucus
Nasal congestion or runny nose
Mild to moderate fever
Fatigue and body aches
Sore throat
Shortness of breath in severe cases

paragraphs: In Children:
list: Breathlessness and wheezing
Persistent cough
High fever
Poor feeding and dehydration, particularly in infants

paragraphs: Understanding how the HMPV respiratory virus spreads is essential to reducing its transmission:
list: Respiratory Droplets: Coughing, sneezing, or talking can release infectious droplets into the air.
Direct Contact: Touching infected individuals or contaminated objects and then touching your face increases the risk of infection.
Airborne Particles: In poorly ventilated areas, airborne particles can linger and spread the virus.
Surface Contamination: The virus can survive on surfaces for hours, creating an additional risk.

paragraphs: Accurate HMPV diagnosis involves clinical evaluations and laboratory tests:
list: HMPV PCR Test: This molecular test detects the virus’s genetic material and is considered the most reliable diagnostic method.
Rapid Antigen Tests: These tests provide faster results but are less sensitive than PCR tests.
Bronchoscopy: In severe cases, this procedure examines the airways to assess damage or blockages.

paragraphs: While most Human Metapneumovirus symptoms resolve within 7–10 days, complications can arise, especially in high-risk individuals:
list: Pneumonia: A severe condition that may require hospitalization and intensive care.
Bronchiolitis: Common in infants, causing inflammation of the small airways, leading to breathing difficulties.
Chronic Condition Exacerbation: Pre-existing conditions like asthma or Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) may worsen due to HMPV symptoms.
Secondary Infections: Bacterial infections such as pneumonia can follow HMPV.
Pregnancy Risks: Severe respiratory symptoms can pose risks to maternal and fetal health.

paragraphs: Currently, there is no specific antiviral HMPV treatment. Symptom management and supportive care are the primary approaches.
Home-Based Care:
list: Rest and Hydration: Adequate rest and fluid intake are essential for recovery.
Over-the-Counter Medications: These help reduce fever and alleviate body aches.
Humidifiers: Using a humidifier can ease nasal congestion and soothe irritated airways.

paragraphs: Hospital-Based Interventions:
list: Oxygen Therapy: To address breathing difficulties.
Intravenous Fluids: To manage dehydration.
Mechanical Ventilation: For life-threatening respiratory complications.

paragraphs: Prevention remains the best defense against HMPV respiratory virus, as there is currently no vaccine available.
Hygiene Practices:
list: Wash your hands frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds.
Avoid touching your face, particularly the eyes, nose, and mouth.
Disinfect frequently touched surfaces, such as doorknobs and mobile devices.
Lifestyle Adjustments:
Maintain a strong immune system through a healthy diet, regular exercise, and sufficient sleep.
Avoid close contact with infected individuals or those displaying respiratory symptoms.

paragraphs: Mask Usage and Isolation:
list: Wear a mask in crowded spaces, particularly during flu seasons or outbreaks.
Self-isolate if you exhibit symptoms to prevent spreading the virus to others.

paragraphs: A recent outbreak in China underscored the severity of Human Metapneumovirus symptoms, especially among children under 14. Many cases required hospitalization due to persistent cough, fever, severe bronchiolitis, and pneumonia. Public health officials emphasized preventive measures such as mask-wearing, frequent handwashing, and early testing to control the virus’s spread.
Understanding Similar Respiratory Viruses
HMPV respiratory virus is often compared to RSV and other respiratory viruses like parainfluenza and adenovirus due to their similar symptoms and transmission methods.
Common Symptoms Across Viruses:
list: Runny nose
Cough
Low-grade fever
Sore throat
Wheezing and difficulty breathing in severe cases

paragraphs: Prevention Strategies for All Respiratory Viruses:
list: Hygiene Practices: Frequent handwashing and surface disinfection.
Vaccination: Annual flu shots and RSV vaccines for eligible individuals.
Healthy Lifestyle: A balanced diet and exercise to boost immunity.

paragraphs: When to Seek Medical Attention
Seek immediate medical care if symptoms include:
list: Difficulty breathing or rapid breathing
Persistent wheezing or bluish skin tone
High fever unresponsive to medication
Indicators of dehydration, such as a dry mouth or decreased urination.

paragraphs: Awareness of Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV)symptoms is essential to minimize its impact. By recognizing HMPV symptoms early, adopting preventive measures, and understanding the risks to vulnerable groups, individuals can protect themselves and their loved ones from this potentially severe respiratory virus.

Have you taken steps to safeguard your health this season? Practice good hygiene, stay informed, and seek medical attention when necessary to reduce the risks of Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV) and similar respiratory infections.

blogs.title: The Impact of Acute Respiratory Failure on Lung Health

medically_reviewed_by.name: Dr. Rama Krishna & Dr. Uma Sri

paragraphs: Acute respiratory failure is a serious health condition that makes breathing difficult. It happens when the lungs can't bring enough oxygen into the blood or eliminate enough carbon dioxide. This can harm organs and requires immediate medical care. It might happen suddenly or through ongoing breathing issues, often called acute and chronic respiratory failure.

sections.heading: What Causes Acute Respiratory Failure?
paragraphs: Several medical conditions can cause acute respiratory failure, including:
list: Pneumonia: Severe lung infections can cause inflammation and fluid buildup in the air sacs, preventing oxygen absorption.
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD): Acute lung failure can result from long-term respiratory conditions in individuals.
Pulmonary Embolism: Blockages in the pulmonary arteries restrict blood flow to the lungs.
Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): Severe lung injury causing extensive inflammation, often due to trauma or severe infections.
Asthma: Airway restrictions due to severe asthma episodes might result in insufficient gas exchange and airflow.
Neuromuscular Disorders: Diseases such as muscular dystrophy and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) can damage respiratory muscles, making breathing difficult.
Inhalation Injuries: Acute lung failure can occur due to breathing in large amounts of smoke or chemical fumes, as well as by inhaling vomit or having near-drowning experiences.
Sepsis: Acute chronic respiratory failure may result from this systemic infection's extensive inflammation, including lung inflammation.
Head, chest or other serious injuries: Head, chest, or other severe injuries can directly harm the lungs or the brain's respiratory centre.

sections.heading: What Raises the Risk of Acute Respiratory Failure?
paragraphs: Acute respiratory failure is more likely to occur in certain situations, particularly in those who already have health problems. Among them are:
list: Individuals with COPD, asthma, or other chronic lung conditions.
Elderly people
A premature baby is more likely to experience respiratory failure if they have newborn respiratory distress due to an underdeveloped lung, pulmonary hypertension, or certain lung birth abnormalities.
Smoking: which damages lung tissue and weakens the immune system.
Excess weight: can restrict lung expansion.
Compromised immune systems: as a result of illicit substances, long-term illnesses, or HIV/AIDS.
Several sedatives used during surgical procedures affect breathing. Respiratory failure may result, particularly if you already have other risk factors.
Occupational exposure to harmful substances such as chemicals, dust, and pollutants.
A lack of exercise weakens heart and lung function.

sections.subheading: Consequences of Acute Respiratory Failure on Lung Health
paragraphs: Lung health is severely compromised by acute respiratory failure, which can have both short-term and long-term effects.
list: High carbon dioxide and low oxygen levels in the blood cause tissue hypoxia and inflammation, which can damage lung tissue and lead to fibrosis and scarring.
Patients often struggle to breathe and need more energy to stay ventilated, which might strain their respiratory muscles and worsen their condition.
Using mechanical ventilation can increase the chances of getting secondary infections, increasing the patient's health challenges.
Patients with a history of acute respiratory failure have a higher risk of mortality, particularly if they experience recurrent episodes or have underlying chronic conditions.

paragraphs: Acute respiratory failure may require immediate hospital diagnosis and emergency care since it can be fatal. Treatment focuses on stabilising the patient, addressing the cause, and supporting the lungs until they can function independently:
Key components of acute respiratory failure treatment include:
list: Oxygen Therapy: Providing additional oxygen to maintain adequate blood oxygen levels.

Mechanical Ventilation: In situations where the patient cannot sustain sufficient breathing on their own, mechanical ventilation could be required. This may include mask-wearing, non-invasive techniques, or invasive techniques like intubation.
Medications: Depending on the cause, treatments may consist of diuretics, bronchodilators, antibiotics, and corticosteroids.
Treating the Underlying Cause: Addressing the root cause, such as infections or flare-ups of chronic diseases.
Supportive Care: Ensuring proper nutrition, fluids, and monitoring, with physical therapy and pulmonary rehabilitation, to strengthen respiratory muscles and improve lung function.

paragraphs: Is it Possible to Avoid Respiratory Failure?

Preventing respiratory failure involves managing underlying conditions and reducing risk factors. Essential strategies include regular medical check-ups and following treatment plans for chronic respiratory diseases like COPD and asthma. Vaccinations against respiratory infections such as influenza and pneumonia are essential for those who are more susceptible, especially people over 65 and those with chronic conditions.

With prompt medical intervention and comprehensive treatment, patients can improve their quality of life and achieve better outcomes. Visit Omni Hospitals today to learn more about the treatment options.

blogs.title: Tuberculosis TB: Symptoms, Causes, & Treatment

medically_reviewed_by.name: Dr. Harika V
medically_reviewed_by.designation: Consultant Infectious Disease Specialist, Omni Hospitals

paragraphs: Tuberculosis (TB) is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis. These bacteria primarily target the lungs and other body parts. The disease traces back thousands of years and has caused havoc across continents, leading to widespread morbidity and mortality. Though there are major medical advancements and efforts to combat the disease, tuberculosis (TB) continues to be a major public health threat.

It is important to understand the causes and symptoms in addition to the importance of timely medical intervention. It can significantly reduce its spread and mortality rate. Moreover, raising awareness and implementing robust public health strategies are necessary steps towards controlling and eliminating Tuberculosis (TB).

sections.heading: Symptoms of Tuberculosis (TB)
paragraphs: Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the bacteria that causes tuberculosis, can infect certain people even when they show no symptoms. These bacteria survive and multiply in the lungs, causing the infection. The symptoms of the Tuberculosis (TB) disease vary depending on the stage of the condition, as mentioned below:

This is the first stage of Tuberculosis (TB) infection, where the immune system cells find and capture the bacteria while destroying them. But sometimes, the captured bacteria might survive and then multiply. During the first stage, most people do not have any symptoms, while some might have flu-like symptoms such as:
list: Low fever
Tiredness
Cough

paragraphs: This is the second stage of infection, in which the immune system builds a wall around the lung tissue with the TB bacteria inside. Hence, the bacteria can do no harm to the body, which is why this stage does not show any symptoms.

When the immune system cannot hold the bacteria inside the wall created by them, the bacteria get out of control and cause infection throughout the lungs and other body parts. This might happen immediately after the primary stage, or it might happen after the latent stage. Symptoms of active Tuberculosis (TB) infection include:
list: Cough
Chest pain
Not feeling well
Fever with chills
Coughing up blood or mucus
Night sweats
Weight loss
Tiredness

sections.heading: Causes and Risk Factors of Tuberculosis (TB)
paragraphs: Tuberculosis is caused by a bacteria called Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which can affect the lungs and voice box and spread to other parts of the body. These diseases are mainly spread when a healthy person is in contact with the infected person for a long time. The immune system may contain the bacteria, leading to a latent TB infection, or fail to do so, allowing the bacteria to multiply and cause active TB disease, damaging lung tissue and possibly spreading to other organs.
Here are some of the risk factors for TB:
list: Compromised Immune System: Individuals with weakened immune systems due to conditions like HIV/AIDS or treatments like chemotherapy are at a significantly higher risk as their bodies are less capable of fighting off TB bacteria.
Contact with TB Patients: Regular close contact with someone who has active TB significantly increases the risk of contracting the infection due to prolonged exposure to the bacteria.
Living Conditions and Overcrowding: People living in overcrowded conditions, such as shelters or prisons, face a higher risk because the close quarters facilitate the spread of TB bacteria.
Socioeconomic Factors: Poverty, malnutrition, and lack of access to medical care can weaken the immune system, making individuals more susceptible to developing TB if exposed.
Substance Abuse: Tobacco and alcohol use can weaken the lung's ability to fight infections and are associated with a higher risk of TB.
Healthcare Work: Healthcare workers are at an increased risk due to more frequent exposure to patients with active TB.
subpara: Airborne droplets contaminated with tuberculosis bacteria spread the disease. Once in the air, anyone in the vicinity can breathe in these droplets. A tuberculosis patient may spread bacteria through snoring, coughing, talking, and singing.

Certain populations are more vulnerable to TB due to factors like compromised healthcare access, living in crowded conditions, and underlying health issues. These conditions make it difficult to prevent exposure to TB and to access timely, effective treatment, thereby increasing the incidence of TB within these communities.

sections.heading: How is Tuberculosis Diagnosed?
paragraphs: Here's how tuberculosis is diagnosed:
Mantoux Tuberculin Skin Test:
list: A small amount of tuberculin is injected under the skin.
The injection site is observed after 48-72 hours for any reaction, indicating TB exposure.
Measure the immune system's response to TB bacteria.
Includes tests like QuantiFERON-TB Gold Plus and T-SPOT.TB.
subpara: Note: Useful especially for those who have received the BCG vaccine or where a skin test might not be practical.

paragraphs: Chest X-rays:
list: Used to detect active TB disease in the lungs.
Provides visual evidence of infection, such as abnormal shadows or patterns.
subpara: Also, doctors recommend sputum tests, in which the healthcare provider may take a sample of mucus that comes up while coughing (sputum). If a person has active TB, a lab test can easily detect the infection. Though it tells if a person has TB bacteria, it might also show bacteria with similar features.
Other lab tests may include -

list: Urine test (urology test)
Breath test
Procedure to remove sputum from lungs with a tube
Tests of the fluid around the spine and brain, called cerebrospinal fluid

paragraphs: The treatment of the TB bacteria depends on the type of TB. If a person has a latent TB infection, doctors might start with drug treatment. This is the best treatment plan for patients with HIV and AIDS or other factors that increase the risk of TB infection.
list: It involves a standard drug regimen, including isoniazid, rifampicin, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide. The treatment must be at least six months to ensure the eradication of TB bacteria and prevent drug resistance.

Treatment of drug-resistant TB strains, multidrug-resistant TB (MDR-TB), and extended drug-resistant TB (XDR-TB) might take up to 24 months or longer, and are costly and sometimes ineffective due to the severity of the condition.

However, there have been some new advancements in TB treatment, with the development of new vaccines and novel therapeutic drugs to improve treatment efficacy. Also, research is putting efforts into biomarkers for faster diagnosis and personalized medicine approaches.
Moreover, their efforts are aimed at reducing treatment duration, combating drug-resistant strains, and customizing therapy to individual needs and the type of TB.

Tuberculosis is a contagious bacterial disease that is transmitted to people who stay in contact with infected people for a longer period. Sometimes, the disease does not show any symptoms, and when they do, the severity of the disease increases, making it challenging to treat appropriately.

Hence, early detection, treatment, and preventive measures are crucial in combating tuberculosis (TB). Timely intervention can prevent the spread and severity of TB. If a person experiences coughing, heavy breathing, spine pain, or any other symptoms that might indicate TB, it is important to seek medical attention.

blogs.title: Bronchoscopy: Procedure, Benefits, Risk & Recovery

paragraphs: Getting a clear view inside the lungs is important for doctors to catch and treat problems early. One way they do this is through a medical test called a bronchoscopy. Let's discuss what this procedure involves.

sections.heading: Bronchoscopy - What is it?
paragraphs: A bronchoscopy involves carefully inserting a long, thin tube equipped with a tiny camera down your throat and into the air passages leading to the lungs. This special scope, a bronchoscope, also has a bright light on the end so the doctor can get a good view of the internal structures.

Most of the time, they'll use a flexible, bendable bronchoscope that can easily wind around all the curves and bends from your mouth to your lungs. But in certain situations with a lot of bleeding or a stuck object, they might opt for a rigid, straight metal version instead. That kind gets inserted under complete anaesthesia at the hospital since it can't flex around those tight corners.

Either way, the idea is to move that camera scope gently down the breathing tube so the doctor can directly inspect the voice box, windpipe, and branching airways that distribute air into the lungs. This gives them an up-close, projected view of any potential issues in those areas that could be causing breathing troubles, lingering coughs, or abnormalities spotted on imaging scans.

The bronchoscopy procedure doesn't just allow for close inspection, though. The doctor can also use that little scope to collect tissue samples, remove mucus blockages, or even deliver medication or treatment.

sections.heading: Why Get a Bronchoscopy?
paragraphs: There are plenty of different reasons why a doctor might recommend this test. Basically, it helps them figure out what's causing breathing issues or other lung problems by allowing that inside inspection.
list: Checking for lung diseases like cancer, COPD, infections, etc.
Looking at any unusual growths or tumours in the lung area
Finding the cause of a chronic, long-lasting cough
Locating the source of bleeding from the lungs
Spotting if something has gotten stuck in a child's airways
subpara: If an X-ray or CT scan hints at an abnormality, a bronchoscopy gives a much clearer picture. During the test, the doctor can also take small tissue samples (biopsies) from the lungs to examine more closely.
Beyond just diagnosis, bronchoscopy can sometimes be used for treatment, too. The doctor can use tiny tools passed through the scope to:

list: Deliver medication right into the airways
Remove mucus plugs or objects blocking the airways
Provide laser therapy to treat small tumours
Insert a little hollow tube (stent) to prop open a narrowed air passage

paragraphs: While it might sound a bit uncomfortable, the bronchoscopy procedure itself is actually pretty straightforward for most people. Here's what the method comprises:
list: Upon arrival, your medical history will be thoroughly discussed. It's essential to give all the details clearly, as some drugs, like blood thinners, might need to be adjusted beforehand.
To keep you relaxed and prevent discomfort, your nose and throat will be numbed with a medicated spray or gel. You'll also get some sedative medicine through an IV line.
The doctor will then gently insert the bronchoscope into your nose or mouth and guide it down your throat slowly and carefully.
As the scope enters the windpipe, the camera will let them see and inspect all the branching airways leading to the lungs. Little puffs of air might be used to obtain a clearer view.

With that up-close view, the doctor can look for any signs of disease, blockages, bleeding or growths. If needed, they can take tissue samples or remove mucus build-up using little tools on the scope.
If there's a blockage, they may put in a hollow stent tube to prop that airway open. Or they could use the scope to deliver concentrated medication right to the problem area.
After a thorough inspection and any treatment, the bronchoscope gets slowly pulled back out. The entire process goes on for around 30 to 60 minutes.
subpara: For a more advanced look, some doctors may use special upgraded scopes like:

list: "Virtual" bronchoscopy that stitches together CT scan visuals into a 3D airway map
Bronchoscopes with a tiny ultrasound probe to see beyond the airway walls
Scopes that use special fluorescent lighting to spot pre-cancerous areas

paragraphs: To make sure your bronchoscopy goes smoothly, here's what you can do:
list: Don't eat or drink anything for about 6-12 hours beforehand as instructed. This prevents food/liquid from getting into your lungs.
Make a list of every single medication, vitamin, supplement etc. that you take regularly. Your doctor may recommend stopping certain ones like blood thinners temporarily before the procedure.
Have a family member or a friend take you home afterwards. The sedation will make it unsafe for you to drive or return to work right away.

sections.heading: Benefits of a Bronchoscopy
paragraphs: While it may sound uncomfortable, a bronchoscopy is an important diagnostic tool that can:
list: Identify the cause of breathing issues or chronic cough
Detect lung diseases, tumours, or infections early
Remove airway obstructions like stuck objects
Deliver medications directly into the lungs
Guide treatment for small tumours using lasers
Open up blocked airways by placing stents
subpara: Getting this inside view can provide life-saving information and target treatment more precisely.

sections.heading: Understanding the Risks
paragraphs: Like most medical procedures, bronchoscopy does carry some risks that you should be aware of upfront. Your doctor will go over your full medical details to determine if the potential benefits outweigh any elevated risks in your case. Some of the most common mild side effects include:
list: A sore, scratchy throat and hoarseness of voice for a day or two afterwards from irritation
Minor bleeding, especially if tissue sampling (biopsies) is performed
Low risk of developing a respiratory infection from the scope introduction
Temporary breathing difficulties or excessive coughing in some cases

paragraphs: More severe but infrequent risks that require prompt treatment include:
list: Partially collapsing a lung (pneumothorax) if air leaks out from an accidental puncture
Severe breathing emergencies like wheezing attacks or respiratory failure
Rare chance of triggering a heart issue like abnormal rhythm or heart attack
subpara: Certain pre-existing conditions like bleeding disorders or heart/lung diseases can potentially increase these risks. But again, your doctor will discuss all of this thoroughly beforehand.

paragraphs: A bronchoscopy is an outpatient procedure, which means you'll go home the same day. Expect to:
list: Rest for 1-2 hours until the sedation wears off and your throats numbness goes away
Have a mildly sore, scratchy throat for a day or two
Avoid eating or drinking until your swallowing reflex fully returns
Take it easy for 24 hours but resume normal activities after that
subpara: Contact your doctor right away if you have worsening symptoms like fever, bleeding, or breathing troubles.

paragraphs: A bronchoscopy gives your doctor a valuable opportunity to thoroughly evaluate the condition of your lungs and airways. While not risk-free, it is a relatively safe procedure that can detect and even treat certain lung issues. Don't hesitate to get one if your doctor recommends it for an accurate diagnosis and effective treatment plan.

blogs.title: The Importance of Lung Health Check-ups

paragraphs: Maintaining good health involves a holistic approach that encompasses various aspects of well-being, among which lung health stands as a crucial pillar. Our lungs, often overlooked in routine health evaluations, play a pivotal role in our overall vitality. Although most individuals don't consider their lung health until a problem starts to show symptoms, it's crucial to take care of our lungs since they are in charge of maintaining the oxygenation of the body's organs, which is necessary for everyday functioning. Regular check-ups for lung health, particularly for individuals with specific risk factors, such as smoking or occupational exposures, can significantly impact early detection and management of potential issues.

sections.heading: Lung health - What is it and why is it important?
paragraphs: Lung health encompasses the adaptability, efficient functioning, and general health of these essential organs that supply oxygen to our bodies. These intricate structures enable the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide. Oxygen is taken up by the blood and distributed throughout the body through the blood vessels after being inhaled. As one exhales, carbon dioxide is released as waste, and air leaves the lungs.

Lung health is important for more than just physical functions; it affects our lifespan and standard of life. The lungs constantly interact with the external environment, making them susceptible to various pollutants, allergens, and harmful substances. Over time, these exposures can lead to inflammation, reduced lung capacity, or even the development of serious conditions like lung cancer or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

Routine checkups are preventative steps that can identify any problems early on in the process for those who have known risk factors, such as smoking or exposure to asbestos or other hazards at work. The prognosis and results of treatment can be greatly enhanced by early issue detection.

sections.heading: Risks for the lung health
paragraphs: Smoking remains one of the most prominent risk factors contributing to compromised lung health. Toxins from cigarette smoke harm lung tissues when inhaled, increasing the risk of respiratory disorders, including COPD and lung cancer. Similarly, individuals working in industries with exposure to harmful substances such as asbestos, silica, or certain chemicals face heightened risks. It may be difficult to avoid environmental contaminants that we come into contact with on a daily basis, such as chemicals, poisons, air pollution, and carcinogens like asbestos in buildings. Lung health may be adversely affected by all of them. Furthermore, typical allergens like mould, pollen, and dust mites can be harmful to the respiratory system. If any or all of these cause one to have symptoms or responses, it might be beneficial to get tested to determine the precise cause of the condition.
Regular lung health evaluations become imperative for these individuals, aiming to identify any adverse effects on lung function promptly.

sections.heading: Common lung conditions
paragraphs: A variety of conditions that affect breathing are included in the category of lung problems. The disorder known as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is common and is marked by restricted airflow and ongoing breathing problems. Another common medical condition that causes coughing, wheezing, and pressure in the chest due to inflammation of the airways is asthma. Fever, coughing, and trouble breathing are signs of pneumonia, an infection that affects the lungs' air sacs. Furthermore, lung cancer, which is characterised by unrestrained cell development in the lungs, is an existential threat to public health. Lung cancer claims more lives than the combined diseases of the breast, colon, and prostate. Due to the detrimental effects on breathing, sleep disturbances are regarded as significant lung diseases. Understanding these conditions is pivotal for early recognition and effective management.

sections.heading: How to maintain the health of your lungs?
paragraphs: The key to preventing respiratory problems from developing into more serious medical diseases is prevention. Here are a few strategies for keeping the lungs healthy:
list: Exercise: Regular physical activity strengthens lung function and capacity. Incorporating activities like brisk walking or swimming aids in maintaining healthy lungs.

Quit Smoking: Our lungs and long-term health are at risk when we smoke. Breathing becomes more difficult due to air channels being narrowed by cigarette smoke. Consider giving up if you smoke. Ceasing smoking significantly reduces the risk of lung diseases, promoting better lung health and overall well-being.

Maintain a Healthy Diet and Stay Hydrated: It is only via the assistance of the lungs that the body can convert food into energy by using oxygen. Our body uses food as fuel. Consuming a balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and lean proteins nourishes the body and supports lung health. Staying adequately hydrated helps maintain the mucosal lining in the lungs, aiding in efficient breathing.

Avoid Exposure to Pollutants: Minimise exposure to air pollutants, such as smoke, smog, or chemicals, to protect the lungs from irritants that can compromise respiratory health. It is inevitable for certain people to be exposed to environmental pollutants. Nonetheless, try to stay indoors and limit the time spent outside when the air quality is classified as "poor".

Stay Up to Date with Vaccinations: Ensuring up-to-date vaccinations, including flu and pneumonia vaccines, fortifies the immune system against infections that can affect respiratory health. Vaccination is the best way to prevent the transmission of infectious respiratory disorders, including influenza, COVID-19, pneumococcal pneumonia, and RSV. These infections are transmitted from person to person.

Maintain Good Hygiene: Practising good hygiene, especially regular handwashing reduces the risk of respiratory infections by preventing the spread of germs. Wearing a mask or avoiding social situations might help prevent one from getting sick or transmitting infections in areas where infection rates are high.

Get Screened Regularly: Undergoing regular lung health screenings, especially if one has risk factors like smoking or occupational exposures, aids in early detection and effective management of potential issues. Regular check-ups contribute to proactive care and timely intervention when necessary. It’s important to schedule routine checkups with a doctor even when you’re feeling good since doing so can help avoid sickness.

sections.heading: Who is eligible for a lung health check?
paragraphs: A lung health check eligibility usually revolves around particular age groups and risk factors, trying to identify those who would most benefit from early detection and preventative care.
list: Smokers: Those with a history of smoking between the ages of 55 and 80 make excellent candidates for lung health assessments. As smoking continues to be a major risk factor for lung illnesses, tests should be conducted on a regular basis to discover any problems early.
Occupational Exposures: Those exposed to harmful substances in their work environment, such as asbestos, silica, or certain chemicals, are eligible for lung health evaluations.
Family History: Screenings may also be beneficial for those with a family history of lung conditions or other risk factors, such as a history of lung infections or persistent respiratory problems.

Consultation with a Doctor: Ultimately, eligibility for lung health checks often involves discussions with a doctor. They assess individual risk factors, medical history, and any symptoms to determine the need and frequency of screenings.

sections.heading: Benefits of Lung Health Check-ups
paragraphs: Regular lung health check-ups offer a multitude of benefits, serving as a cornerstone of proactive healthcare. Here are a key advantage:
list: Routine screenings enable early identification of potential lung issues, even before symptoms manifest. This early detection often leads to more successful treatment outcomes and better prognosis.

Individuals with risk factors like smoking history or occupational exposures can undergo specialised evaluations to assess their lung health status. These assessments provide insights into potential risks and guide personalised preventive measures.
Regular check-ups include tests to assess lung capacity and function. Tracking changes in lung health over time enables timely interventions and tailored treatment plans if any abnormalities arise.

Regular lung health check-ups aid doctors in tailoring personalised treatment strategies for managing and preventing the spread of lung diseases. By closely monitoring the progression or development of conditions, doctors can devise precise, customised approaches.

Understanding one's lung health status empowers individuals to make informed decisions about lifestyle changes, such as quitting smoking or adopting healthier habits, fostering a proactive approach to health.

sections.heading: Lung Health Check-ups at Omni Hospital
paragraphs: Omni Hospital understands that maintaining lung health is critical to maintaining overall wellbeing. Our comprehensive lung health check-ups are designed to assess, diagnose, and prevent potential issues related to lung health. At Omni Hospital, we prioritize early detection and prevention, empowering individuals to take charge of their lung health and pave the way towards a healthier future.

blogs.title: Pneumonia: Causes, Symptoms, and Treatment

sections.heading: Pneumonia Overview
paragraphs: Pneumonia is a serious lung infection that affects people across age groups. Being well-informed can help people seek timely care when required and also take preventive measures. Therefore, we have provided a comprehensive guide to pneumonia by exploring its causes, risk factors, types, symptoms, diagnosis, and treatment options.

sections.heading: What is Pneumonia?
paragraphs: Pneumonia is swelling of the lungs' air passageways.
list: As the air sacs become filled with serum and pus, circulation in the blood is obstructed.
Symptoms include chest pain, fever, cough and difficulty of breathing.
The risk factors vary depending on the severity of the disease.

paragraphs: Pneumonia symptoms can vary as per the causes and severity of infection. However, typical signs associated with include:

list: Chest pain, especially while breathing deeply
Confusion and behavioural changes, especially in elderly patients
Persistent cough with thick yellow/greenish/bloody mucus
Fever with chills, sweats, headaches, and loss of appetite
Fatigue with low energy levels
Shortness of breath, even with little activity
Nausea, vomiting, or diarrhoea
Fever with coughing
Lack of interest in eating
Excessive crying, lethargy
Very fast breathing is visible in the ribcage
Body temperature lower than normal
Pre-existing illnesses worsening
Mental confusion and behavioural changes

sections.heading: What Are the Types of Pneumonia?
paragraphs: The types of pneumonia include:

subsections.subheading: Depending on the Location of Acquisition
list: Community-Acquired Pneumonia (CAP): People catch this common type of lung infection outside of hospitals and healthcare facilities.
Hospital-Acquired Pneumonia (HAP): Occurs in patients admitted to hospitals for some other illness. It involves more chronic diseases and antibiotic-resistant bacteria.
Healthcare-Associated Pneumonia (HCAP): Developed at nursing homes, dialysis centres, and clinics. Similar risks as HAP.
Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): Occurs in people on ventilators due to compromised lung defence mechanisms.
Aspiration Pneumonia: Caused by inhaling food/drink into the lungs, seen in people with swallowing difficulties.
Bacterial: The most common variety is triggered by bacteria like Streptococcus Pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus, and Mycoplasma pneumonia.
Viral: Caused by influenza, COVID-19, and respiratory syncytial virus (RSV). It is usually mild but can be fatal for certain groups.
Fungal: Seen in people with chronic diseases or weakened immunity due to fungi.
Protozoal: Rare pneumonia caused by protozoa like Toxoplasma.

subsections.subheading: Depending on the Pattern of Lung Inflammation
list: Lobar: Infects one or more sections (lobes) of the lungs, common in bacterial cases.
Bronchopneumonia: Infects patches throughout both lungs, more common in viral infections.
Interstitial: Infects the interstitial tissue of the lungs.

sections.heading: Causes of Pneumonia
paragraphs: Pneumonia can occur due to various infectious pathogens as well as aspiration events such as:

Bacteria are the most common infectious cause of pneumonia. Streptococcus Pneumoniae tops the list, causing up to 50% of pneumonia cases. This gram-positive bacteria has over 90 known serotypes that make it harder to develop universal vaccines against. It spreads via respiratory droplet transmission from carriers.
Other common bacterial pneumonia culprits are:
list: Staphylococcus Aureus: Mostly methicillin-resistant strains (MRSA) trigger healthcare-associated pneumonia in hospitals when immunity is lowered.
Mycoplasma Pneumoniae: Atypical bacteria lacking cell walls cause 'Walking Pneumonia' with milder symptoms. Common in school-aged children.
Chlamydophila Pneumoniae: Also an atypical bacteria, it is linked to gradually worsening symptoms when turning chronic and more challenging to diagnose.
Legionella Pneumophila: Gram-negative bacteria that colonise water reservoirs and infect lungs by inhaling droplets from air conditioning, humidifiers, and fountains.

paragraphs: Viruses are the second most common cause of infectious pneumonia. Leading viral culprits are:
list: Influenza: Seasonal flu viruses damage airway linings every year and can turn fatal for high-risk groups. This includes influenza A, B and C strains.
COVID-19: The novel SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus caused waves of viral pneumonia with respiratory distress during the recent pandemic.
Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV): A common cause of pneumonia in infants and young kids, especially in winter months.

paragraphs: Certain fungi can trigger pneumonia in immunocompromised people; these include:
list: Pneumocystis Jirovecii: This yeast-like fungus causes a form of pneumonia called PCP in HIV-positive people with very low T-cell counts.
Cryptococcus Neoformans: Found in soil, it can infect lung tissue, more fatal in organ transplant recipients on immunosuppressive therapy.
Histoplasma Capsulatum: Inhaling airborne spores of this dimorphic fungus can lead to acute lung infections.
Coccidioides Immitis and Coccidioides Posadasii: Also called valley fever or desert rheumatism, these soil fungi can cause community-acquired pneumonia when spores are stirred into the air.

sections.heading: Risk factors
paragraphs: People at higher risk for pneumonia include:
list: Age: Very young children and adults above 65 years
Hospitalised patients, especially those with chronic diseases
Lung diseases like COPD, asthma that affect airway clearance
Smoking and excessive alcohol consumption
Weak immune system due to HIV, organ transplant, chemotherapy
Taking food, liquids, or vomit into the lungs due to swallowing difficulties

sections.heading: Diagnosis
paragraphs: As pneumonia symptoms can be vague, diagnostic tests are required to ascertain it. Hence, the diagnosis of pneumonia can include:
list: A physical examination checks vital parameters like temperature, blood pressure, and heart rate and also involves checking the chest with a stethoscope to listen to abnormal lung sounds.
Breathing and oxygenation tests are done using pulse oximetry, which measures oxygen saturation levels in the blood via a sensor probe.
Blood tests assess markers like white blood cell counts, which indicate infection when elevated. These help narrow down potential causative agents.

Microbiological testing involves taking sputum samples coughed out by the patient and analysing them. The presence of pathogenic bacteria or fungi confirms pneumonia. This also allows for testing antibiotic efficacy.
Imaging tests like chest X-rays and CT scans visualise the lungs and highlight areas of infection as opacities or inflamed spots. These also help track disease progression.

If there is fluid accumulation surrounding the lungs, known as pleural effusion, samples may be collected using a needle and sent for pleural fluid culture to confirm pneumonia diagnosis and design targeted treatment plans accordingly.
In some difficult cases, physicians may perform bronchoscopy by inserting an endoscope tube with a camera into the airways to view the lungs from inside and take fluid or tissue samples if required.

sections.heading: Treatment Procedures
paragraphs: The pneumonia treatment plan is customised as per the type identified from tests and the severity of the infection. Some options can include:
Bacterial Pneumonia Care: Antibiotics like Amoxicillin, Azithromycin, and Doxycycline depending on antibiotic sensitivity results.
Viral Pneumonia Care: Includes mostly symptomatic treatment - rest, fluids, fever/cough medication.

list: Cough suppressants, throat lozenges
Ibuprofen and Acetaminophen for pain and fever
Chest physiotherapy for mucus drainage
Oxygen support if blood oxygen levels are very low
Hospitalisation in ICU
IV antibiotic injections
Ventilator support
Pleural fluid drainage, if required
subpara: In most cases, pneumonia resolves within 1-3 weeks of medical treatment. Completing the entire course of antibiotics is essential, even if you start to feel better.

paragraphs: Prevention Tips
Some ways to prevent pneumonia infections include:
list: Get vaccinated against common pneumonia-causing agents like influenza, Streptococcus Pneumoniae, COVID-19
Practise good hygiene - cover mouth while sneezing or coughing, and wash hands regularly
Manage any chronic lung condition diligently with medical care
Improve immunity with a balanced diet and regular exercise

paragraphs: Pneumonia can result from various lung pathogens and can range from mild to fatal. Timely medical care guided by on-time diagnosis allows for appropriate treatment. One can also take preventive measures by limiting controllable risk factors and getting vaccinated.
Creating awareness about pneumonia is key, especially among at-risk groups like infants and the elderly.

blogs.title: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) Awareness

paragraphs: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is an umbrella term for a group of lung conditions, including emphysema, non reversible asthma, chronic bronchitis and certain types of bronchiectasis. These conditions can occur in combination. According to research conducted by the World Health Organization COPD affects a varying percentage of adults ranging from 4% to 20%. The primary causes of Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease are. Air pollution, which often leads to health issues among those affected. The lack of ventilation in homes exacerbates the situation further. Since COPD is a disease its symptoms gradually interfere with activities and worsen over time. While Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is a health condition, early detection, appropriate treatment and preventive measures all rely on awareness. Being well informed about Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) helps individuals recognize symptoms promptly, implement measures effectively and seek medical attention.

sections.heading: What is Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)?
paragraphs: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is a continual situation marked by using permanent lung deterioration, growing breathing difficulties, and airway blockage. Emphysema and persistent bronchitis are the two important conditions which can be grouped together below the term COPD. The severity of every of those problems varies from man to woman, and someone with COPD may additionally have one or each of them.
The lungs' air sacs go through damage from emphysema. As a result, the lungs become much less bendy and feature problems changing carbon dioxide and oxygen.

The lining of the airways will become inflamed in instances of chronic bronchitis. Mucus thickens and is produced in extra portions as a result. When bronchitis is persistent and is not relieved, it is considered persistent.

A record of asthma can raise the threat of having Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and asthma signs and symptoms may coexist with the circumstance. Airways that are infected due to bronchial asthma flare up and respond excessively to things breathed.

sections.subheading: What is Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease Awareness?
paragraphs: Even though COPD is a relatively prevalent lung disease, not many individuals are aware of it or know how to avoid it. COPD was shown to be significantly misrepresented in relation to its frequency and impact on global health in a 2019 research evaluating public interest in the disease using data from Google searches conducted between 2004 and 2018. Numerous studies, like this one, show how urgently COPD awareness has to be raised.

Increasing public knowledge of COPD aims to increase focus on the condition, as well as on available preventative and treatment strategies. The goal of COPD awareness is to raise awareness of the disease and the prevention and treatment options available for it. This might eventually reduce the prevalence of COPD and enhance the life expectancy and quality of life for those who already have it.

National COPD Awareness Month falls in November. In order to inform and educate others about COPD, members of the community gather together during this period. By being informed of the signs, symptoms, and treatment options for COPD, we can all strive to raise awareness of the illness and enhance the lives of individuals who are impacted by this difficult condition. Thus, let us exchange insights, offer assistance, and contribute to the battle against COPD.

sections.heading: Why is COPD Awareness Important?
list: It can encourage patients to seek treatment by assisting them in identifying COPD symptoms and indications early. Increasing people's access to early treatment may help them live longer and have higher-quality lives.
It could make individuals less likely to smoke and more likely to take precautions while handling potentially harmful materials.
Increased financing for testing, treatment, and outreach initiatives are just a few examples of the political and public health actions it may trigger.
It can assist in debunking myths regarding COPD, such as the idea that smoking is the cause of every case.
It increases knowledge of the risks posed by air pollution.

paragraphs: Identifying COPD symptoms early can significantly improve prognosis. The symptoms may be mild at first, with occasional coughing and shortness of breath. As the disease worsens, symptoms might become more frequent, making it harder to breathe.
Early signs and symptoms include:

list: Shortness of breath, especially following exercise.
A slight but recurring cough.
Frequent throat clearing, especially in the morning.

paragraphs: It might become more difficult to ignore symptoms as they worsen. As the lungs degenerate further, you may experience:
list: Breathing difficulties, even following easy physical activities like climbing stairs.
Wheezing, a loud, elevated-pitched breathing pattern that typically happens during exhalations
Prolonged cough, with or without mucus.
The need to remove mucus from your lungs every day.
Regular occurrences of colds, flu, or other respiratory diseases.
Fatigue.
Swelling of the feet, ankles, or legs.
Weight loss.

paragraphs: The causes of COPD are:
list: The primary cause is smoking. However, some people smoke for years without ever developing COPD.
Although it is uncommon, those who do not smoke might nevertheless get COPD. It is brought on by exposure to alpha-1 antitrypsin protein and may progress to emphysema.
Individuals with a history of asthma and smoking are most vulnerable to COPD.
Exposure to certain gasses or pollutants at work.
Pollutant exposure, both inside and outdoors.
COPD develops progressively in a person over time. As a result, symptoms are more likely to emerge between the ages of 35 and 40.
Frequently using a cooking fire without enough ventilation.

AAT deficiency is a rare genetic condition that accounts for a tiny percentage of COPD cases. Compared to when the condition is brought on by smoking, symptoms of COPD that are caused by AAT deficiency typically appear earlier in life.

sections.heading: How Does COPD Affect People’s Lives?
paragraphs: COPD significantly impacts individuals' daily lives and overall well-being. Breathing difficulties and persistent symptoms lead to reduced physical activity, social isolation, anxiety, and depression. The progression of the disease often requires frequent hospitalisations and imposes a substantial economic burden due to healthcare costs and lost productivity. Moreover, COPD may increase the risk of developing other conditions such as heart disease, lung cancer, and respiratory failure.

sections.heading: Treatments for COPD
paragraphs: While COPD is incurable, various treatments aim to alleviate symptoms, improve lung function, and enhance the quality of life. Several therapeutic options are available for COPD.
list: The main treatments involve inhaling medications that open and relieve edema in the airways.
Medications such as bronchodilators, inhaled corticosteroids, and antibiotics help manage symptoms and prevent worsening of the condition.
Antibiotics and steroid tablets are frequently used to treat flare-ups.
Those with severe COPD or those who have had the disease for a long period are treated with oxygen.
Pulmonary rehabilitation, oxygen therapy, and vaccination against flu and pneumonia are also essential components of COPD management.
In severe cases, surgical interventions like lung volume reduction or lung transplantation may be considered.
Certain inhalers clear the airways and can be used on a daily basis to lessen or avoid symptoms, as well as to ease discomfort during sudden flare-ups.
Sometimes, they are used with inhaled corticosteroids to reduce lung inflammation.
People may receive steroid pills or antibiotics in addition to inhaled or nebulized medication as needed, as flare-ups can often result from respiratory infections.

sections.heading: Preventive Measures for COPD
paragraphs: Preventing COPD primarily involves reducing exposure to risk factors. Modifying one's lifestyle can help reduce COPD symptoms. Quitting smoking is the most effective measure to prevent COPD progression. Avoiding exposure to air pollutants, wearing protective masks in polluted environments, and minimizing occupational hazards play a crucial role. Regular exercise and maintaining a healthy diet are also beneficial in preventing complications associated with COPD.
Take precautions to avoid lung infections:
list: Get a flu vaccine every year.
Get the pneumonia vaccine.
Receive every available COVID-19 vaccination, and confirm that you have had the most recent booster shots.

paragraphs: COPD is a debilitating respiratory condition affecting millions globally. Awareness, early detection, and proper management are critical in mitigating its effects and improving patients’ lives. By spreading awareness, supporting those affected, and advocating preventive measures, we can collectively make strides in improving the lives of individuals battling COPD.

Omni Hospitals stands out as a leading healthcare provider committed to excellence in COPD care. With state-of-the-art facilities and a dedicated team of pulmonologists, respiratory therapists, and support staff, Omni Hospitals ensures comprehensive COPD management. From accurate diagnosis to personalized treatment plans and ongoing support, Omni Hospitals prioritizes patient well-being, offering a holistic approach to COPD care.

blogs.title: Understanding Acute vs. Chronic Bronchitis: What You Need to Know

subsections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: Bronchitis is caused by an infection in the bronchial tube lining, which carries air to and from the lungs. People with bronchitis usually cough up thick and discoloured mucus. It is often developed from a cold or respiratory infection.

There are two types of bronchitis: acute and chronic bronchitis. Acute bronchitis is common, whereas chronic bronchitis is serious and causes inflammation and irritation in the bronchial tube lining. This condition mostly occurs due to smoking. Acute bronchitis is also known as a chest cold. It improves within 10 days; however, the cough might persist for weeks. It also requires medical attention and is one of the conditions included in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
In this blog, we will discuss acute vs chronic bronchitis symptoms in detail.

subsections.heading: Acute Bronchitis
paragraphs: Acute bronchitis is an infectious viral illness characterised by inflammation and irritation of the bronchial tubes, which are responsible for transporting air to the lungs. When the bronchial tubes become infected, they swell and produce viscous mucus, narrowing the tubes and making it difficult for the person to breathe.
Bacterial and viral infections, environmental factors, and other lung diseases can cause acute bronchitis.
list: Viral Infections: Approximately 85 to 95 percent of adult cases of acute bronchitis are caused by viruses. Typically, acute bronchitis is triggered by the same viruses responsible for the common cold or flu.
Other Lung Conditions: Acute bronchitis can occasionally develop in individuals with asthma.
Irritating Substances: Inhaling irritants such as smoke, smog, and chemical fumes can inflame the trachea and bronchial tubes, potentially leading to acute bronchitis.

Bacterial Infections: In rare cases, viral bronchitis can progress to bacterial bronchitis. This can occur due to infections caused by bacteria such as Chlamydia pneumoniae, Bordetella pertussis, and Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

subsections.paragraphs: The risk factors for acute bronchitis include the following:
list: Inhaling smoke from cigarette consumption, including passive smoking.
Having a weaker immune system or reduced resistance to infection.
Acid reflux.
Regular exposure to irritants such as dust or chemical fumes.
Age greater than 50.
Lack of vaccination for whooping cough, pneumonia, or flu.

paragraphs: There are two types of symptoms that a person can experience:
Emergency Symptoms
The following are the symptoms that require immediate medical attention:
list: Loud barking cough
Unexplained weight loss
Chest pain
Trouble breathing
100.4 degrees Fahrenheit fever
Cough lasting for 10 days or longer

paragraphs: Typical Symptoms
The initial symptoms of acute bronchitis are similar to cold and flu. Some of them are mentioned below:
list: Sneezing
Wheezing
Runny nose
Sore throat
Sensitivity to cold
Body aches
Fever
Cough with green or yellow mucus

paragraphs: Some rare symptoms are as follows:
list: Nausea
Vomiting
Diarrhoea

subsections.paragraphs: It is important to see a doctor when a person experiences any symptoms. Upon visiting the doctor, they will perform physical examinations, focus on breathing patterns, and ask about symptoms. Some diagnostic tests include:
list: Chest X-Ray: If pneumonia or another ailment is expected to be the cause of the cough, a chest X-ray can assist in diagnosing it.
Lung Function Examination: Performed with a spirometer to assess lung capacity and airflow, useful in diagnosing asthma or emphysema.
Sputum Testing: Identifies pathogens that can be treated with antibiotics and screens for allergies.

paragraphs: Doctors usually do not provide medication to treat acute bronchitis unless the symptoms are severe. Instead, they suggest homecare treatment. Here's what a person with acute bronchitis can do:
list: Use a humidifier to add moisture to the air and relieve mucus.
Add ginger to tea or hot water to soothe the bronchial passages.
Consume lots of fluids to thin mucus.
Use dark honey to relieve cough.
Take OTC nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs for throat pain.
subsections.subpara: It is important to understand that acute bronchitis is viral and doesn't respond to antibiotics unless there's a pneumonia risk.

paragraphs: Chronic bronchitis is an inflammation caused by various factors, mainly smoking and viruses. It causes coughing and shortness of breath. The body reacts by producing mucus and inflaming airways.
The main contributor to chronic bronchitis is smoking. Other contributing factors include:
list: Dust
Smoke inhalation
Burnt coal and smoke
Engine emissions, welding fumes, air pollution
Chemical vapours (e.g., paint, hairspray)
Allergens
Pollution
Smoking (including passive)
Family history
Asthma
Childhood respiratory illnesses

subsections.subheading: C. Symptoms and chronic bronchitis diagnosis
paragraphs: Chronic bronchitis causes mucus buildup, persistent cough, and difficulty breathing. Additional symptoms include:
list: Wheezing
Slender chest
Fatigue
Breathing difficulty
Frequent coughing with mucus

subsections.paragraphs: Symptoms worsen during winter. Diagnosis involves physical exam and the following tests:
list: CT X-Ray: To examine lung condition.
Spirometry: Measures lung function.
Pulse Oximetry: Measures blood oxygen levels.
Arterial Blood Gas: Evaluates oxygen and CO2 exchange.

paragraphs: Here's what doctors at OMNI Hospital may recommend:
list: Antibiotics: For bacterial or viral infections.
Oxygen Treatment: Helps with breathing.
Bronchodilators: Relaxes airway muscles.
Pulmonary Rehabilitation: Includes exercise, nutrition, education, and counselling.
Avoid tobacco and passive smoke.
Avoid pollution and lung irritants.
Treat respiratory problems like asthma early.

sections.heading: IV. Differences between Acute and Chronic Bronchitis

paragraphs: Acute bronchitis resolves within days to a week, often from infection. Chronic bronchitis is persistent and may worsen over time.

The main causes of acute bronchitis are viruses such as rhinovirus (the virus causing the common cold), Influenza A and B (causes of the common flu). Some bacteria such as Mycoplasma Pneumoniae, Streptococcus Pneumoniae, Moraxella Catarrhalis, etc., also cause acute bronchitis.
On the other hand, chronic bronchitis is caused due to genetics, age, asthma, and allergies that require immediate medical attention.
Acute bronchitis does not affect the lungs, whereas chronic bronchitis, which occurs along with pneumonia, affects the lungs.
Usually, people recover from acute bronchitis, but a very few people develop bacterial infections such as pneumonia in the long term.
On the other hand, people suffering from chronic bronchitis can develop conditions such as COPD (Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease). It also causes muscle spasms and inflammation.

sections.heading: V. Prevention and Lifestyle Tips
paragraphs: Below are ways to prevent bronchitis:
list: Smoking Cessation - Smoking causes several respiratory diseases, including bronchitis. Therefore, quitting tobacco (both active and passive smoking) can help prevent and reduce the risk of acute and chronic bronchitis.
Avoiding Environmental Pollutants - Individuals living in areas with high pollution are at a higher risk of developing acute and chronic bronchitis. It is advisable to wear a mask when going outside.

Practising Good Respiratory Hygiene - Practising yoga and asanas are excellent ways to improve the respiratory system. Additionally, maintaining a healthy diet, engaging in regular exercise for 30-40 minutes a day, and consuming nutritious food can help maintain good respiratory hygiene.
sections.subpara: Strengthening the Immune System - The most effective method to strengthen the immune system is to maintain a healthy diet, receive vaccinations, refrain from consuming alcohol, maintain a healthy weight, etc. Additionally, minimising stress can boost the immune system.

paragraphs: Bronchitis is a common respiratory condition, which viral infections can cause. However, it can be reduced by eliminating the flu, the common cold, or other respiratory illnesses. Additionally, practising good hygiene, such as frequent hand washing, can help prevent the spread of viral diseases. It is advisable to quit smoking and minimise exposure to environmental chemicals in order to prevent bronchitis.

Acute bronchitis can be treated with home remedies. However, for chronic bronchitis, it is important for a person to visit the doctor to ensure that the condition does not worsen. At OMNI Hospital, we have the best doctors for bronchitis who will treat the condition with their expertise and knowledge. Call us today to book a consultation!

blogs.title: Impact Of Smoking On The Body And Tips On How To Quit

paragraphs: Tobacco has been around for centuries, yet we only recently learned about the health impact of smoking. Smokers usually die 10 years sooner than non-smokers. By deciding to stop smoking, you can improve your health and life expectancy.

Experts have known that impact of smoking causes lung cancer and tobacco hurts your health in a variety of ways, including cancer and chronic (long-term) disorders. Smoking-related diseases claim the lives of approximately 480,000 people each year. It also indicated that for every smoker who dies, at least 30 more people suffer from a major smoking-related ailment.

sections.subheading: Forms Of Tobacco: Impact of Smoking
paragraphs: Many individuals assume that smoking a cigar is a safer alternative to smoking cigarettes. Cigar smokers, on the other hand, are exposed to many of the same health concerns as cigarette smokers, including cancer. Chewing tobacco or smokeless tobacco is no less dangerous than normal cigarettes. There are nearly 30 new types of cancers that are found in smokeless tobacco.

The electronic vape is a type of cigarette that delivers the nicotine delivery system. These are called traditional tobacco products. In a smokeless inhaled mist, vaping delivers more concentrated nicotine than cigarettes (vapour). If you have asthma or chronic obstructive lung disease, or cancer are among the health hazards associated with vape devices.

Tobacco usage affects all of your body’s organs. Tobacco smoke introduces not only nicotine but also over 5,000 chemicals into your lungs, blood, and organs, including several carcinogens (cancer-causing compounds).

The other serious impact of smoking on health are that it can reduce the potential of life and dramatically affect longevity. Besides, smoking is the leading cause of mortality in the world. Moreover, pregnant moms who smoke can endanger their unborn children.

sections.paragraphs: The following are some of the possible pregnancy side effects-
list: Ectopic Pregnancy
Miscarriages
Stillbirths
Birth Defects
Low Birthweight
subpara: Nicotine addiction is a possibility with smokeless tobacco. Chewing tobacco users are at risk for developing mouth, esophageal, and pancreatic cancers. Gum disease, Dental Decay, and tooth loss are all linked to chewing tobacco.

E-cigarettes’ safety and risks are still unknown. Many e-cigarettes have high nicotine content. Vaping is the gateway to other nicotine products. These can be cigarettes or chewing tobacco. There are many harmful compounds found in the vapour of e-cigarettes. You can inhale these vape components which can result in the condition EVALI or fatal lung damage.

paragraphs: All the diagnostic tests are based on the symptoms you’re going through. For example, a smoker who develops stomach cancer after drinking nicotine-laced juice will require different tests than someone who inhales the smoke.

If you smoke, your healthcare professional will inquire about your tobacco use, evaluate you physically, and occasionally prescribe testing (like an X-ray to check for organ damage or an electrocardiogram and other heart-related tests).

Smoking, in addition to the established cancer dangers, causes a slew of other chronic (long-term) health issues that necessitate continuing treatment. Treatment is required for the following smoking-related problems:
list: Increased Blood Pressure and decreased HDL (good) cholesterol (increasing risks for heart attack and stroke).
Erectile Dysfunction
Reduced oxygen supply to the heart and other bodily parts (increasing risks for coronary artery disease, peripheral artery disease, and diabetes).
Routine ailments like the colds, especially in youngsters.
COPD, Asthma, Bronchitis, and Emphysema are the reasons for poor lung function.

paragraphs: A healthcare provider can treat the majority of smoking-related illnesses. The following items may be required-
list: To address any damage to your heart, you'll need to see a Cardiologist.
To treat breathing disorders such as COPD, you'll need a lung expert.
You'll be treated by an oncology team if you develop cancer.

paragraphs: One of the best ways to avoid such ill impact of smoking is to never start. One should quit it as soon as they start. It can help to reverse health issues. One can do these to avoid smoking-
list: Live Longer
You can decrease the chances of heart attack or stroke.
Reduce your chances of contracting a number of other illnesses
Have more energy and feel better
Improve your appearance and mood
Improve your olfactory and gustatory abilities
Make financial savings

sections.subheading: Quit Smoking For a Healthy Life
paragraphs: There are numerous methods answering your cliche question of how to quit smoking. One has to select a cessation of skiing strategy to get lucky. And it has to suit your personality. You must be emotionally and mentally prepared. You should want to stop smoking for yourself, not merely for the sake of your family and friends who are exposed to secondhand smoke.
We have a few ideas that can help you in quitting smoking-
list: You’ve to get all the cigarettes and lighters along with ashtrays away from home. Anything that makes you smoke should be kept away.
If you have a roommate who is a smoker, ask them to request not to do so in front of you. You can also make them quit the same.
Please don’t take your urges seriously. Strike them and have ways to cope with quitting.
You’ve to keep your hands occupied. Doodle or write something that can keep you away from smoking. You can also read a book or go to the gym for a change.

Take a big breath when you feel compelled to smoke. Slowly release it after ten seconds. Repeat this process until you no longer have the need to smoke. Meditation can also be used to lower stress levels.
Avoid smoking-friendly places, persons, and situations. Go places that don't allow smoking or hang out with nonsmokers (like movies, museums, shops, or libraries).

Don't try to replace smoke with food or sugar-based items. These have the potential to make people acquire weight. Choose low-calorie, high-nutrient foods instead. Veggie sticks, sugar-free hard candies, or chewing gum are all good options.
Limit alcoholic and caffeinated beverages while drinking lots of water. Smoking impulses may be triggered by them.
Make a belief that you’re not a smoker.
Remember to exercise because it is good for your health and might help you relax.
subpara: These are some ways that can help you with how to stop smoking. Quitting smoking improves your health at any age. Smoking-related harm can be reversed over time. When you’ll quit the smoking, you’ll get many benefits-

list: Your blood pressure and pulse rate drop after 20 minutes, while the temperature of your hands and feet rise. You also cease polluting the atmosphere.
All the carbon monoxide will have low quantities and more oxygen within 8 hours.
Your risk of a heart attack falls after 24 hours.
A lack of nicotine will provide a taste and smell after 48 hours.
Your circulation improves after two to three months, and you can handle more exertion.
Energy levels will come again and after 1-9 months you’ll cough less. All the nasal, congestion and breath shortness will also get reduced.
If you compare them to smokers, your risk of Heart stroke will decrease.
You will have a decreased chance of stroke after 5 to 15 years of smoking.

After ten years, your chances of dying from lung cancer are nearly identical to those of a lifetime nonsmoker. The malignancies will be reduced and you can cope with them easily as a result of quitting Smoking.
After 15 years, your risk of heart disease has finally caught up to that of nonsmokers.

paragraphs: When you're ready to quit smoking, there are several ways available to help you. Medical clinics, neighbourhood pharmacies, and support groups are all available to assist you in quitting smoking. When you try to quit smoking, apps and websites provide support and accountability.
