blogs.title: Choosing the Right Surgeon for Pacemaker Implantation Surgery
blogs.medically_reviewed_by: Dr. Pramod Kumar, Senior Cardiologist

paragraphs: It is critical to ensure optimal cardiac health and to choose the best surgeon for pacemaker placement surgery. A pacemaker is a medical device that is implanted to keep the heart beating in a consistent and safe rhythm. Pacemakers can be used to treat a range of medical disorders, including bradycardia, heart failure, and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (an enlarged heart). If your doctor sets a pacemaker for you, you'll need to find the best professional for the treatment.

Electrical impulses regulate the heart’s rhythm, synchronising its contractions for adequate blood circulation. Disturbances in this electrical system, however, can cause irregular heartbeats, which can cause exhaustion, lightheadedness, dyspnea, and even fainting. These problems are intended to be addressed by pacemaker insertion surgery, which offers patients a dependable means of preserving a normal cardiac rhythm. The goal of pacemaker surgery, often called pacemaker implantation surgery, is to implant a tiny electronic device called a pacemaker to treat abnormal cardiac rhythms. By applying electrical impulses to the cardiac muscles, this device controls the heartbeat and maintains a regular and stable rhythm. People with disorders like bradycardia or arrhythmias (irregular heart rhythms) that are not well controlled with medicine alone are usually advised to have a pacemaker surgically implanted.

To reach the heart during the procedure, the surgeon creates a tiny incision in the patient's chest. The pacemaker is then implanted beneath the skin close to the collarbone and attached to the heart. It is a pulse generator, one or more leads, and an electrode on each lead. The leads are inserted into the heart chambers by delicately weaving them through blood arteries, where they transmit electrical impulses that control the heartbeat. The incision is closed when the device is in place, and the patient is attentively watched as they recover.

sections.subheading: Things to Take Into Account Before Selecting a Pacemaker Surgeon
paragraphs: A seamless and effective pacemaker surgery process depends on selecting the best healthcare professional. To assist you in making an educated choice, consider these crucial steps:
list: Ask for Referrals: To start your search, get referrals from your cardiologist and dependable friends and family members who have had similar surgeries. Seek a surgeon with a strong history of favourable outcomes and a wealth of expertise in heart surgery. Their experiences can provide important insights regarding the calibre of care various medical professionals offer.

Do Extensive Research: Invest some time in conducting a comprehensive study on possible healthcare providers. Verify details on their qualifications, background, and patient satisfaction scores. A few good places to look for this information include professional associations, hospital websites, and internet review services.

Take Reputation into Account: Consider each healthcare provider's standing in the medical community and with previous clients. Seek out medical professionals who have demonstrated a commitment to providing patients with high-quality care and favourable results. Look for patient reviews and testimonials to learn more about the surgeon's clinical manner, communication abilities, and general patient paragraphsment. Positive comments from past clients may give you more confidence in your choice.

Board Certification: A healthcare professional who has earned board certification has completed specialised training and satisfied the high requirements established by their specific medical board. It is imperative to select a surgeon board-certified in either electrophysiology or cardiac surgery for pacemaker surgery. This accreditation guarantees the surgeon's proficiency and ability to carry out intricate cardiac treatments safely and efficiently.

Hospital Affiliation: The quality of treatment given to patients having pacemaker surgery largely depends on the hospital where a doctor practices. Seek out a hospital that performs many pacemaker insertion procedures, has a specialised cardiac unit, and has advanced equipment. Hospitals that offer complete cardiac care facilities are better suited to manage possible issues and give patients the best possible treatment throughout surgery and the convalescence phase.

Technological Progress: Medical technological breakthroughs have transformed Pacemaker surgery techniques, providing patients with less invasive treatments and cutting-edge device alternatives. Ask your healthcare provider about their experience with the most recent technical developments in heart care when selecting them for a pacemaker operation. Medical providers that remain up to date on the latest methods and equipment can provide patients with modern facilities and alternatives for treatment that could improve their quality of life and results.

Set Up Consultations: After you've narrowed down your list of possible doctors, you can set up in-person meetings with them by scheduling consultations. Take advantage of this chance to inquire about their expertise with pacemaker surgery, patient care philosophy, and any requests or worries you may have.

Accessibility and Follow-Up Care: Following pacemaker surgery, accessibility and follow-up care are essential aspects of the patient experience. Select a doctor who values prompt follow-up appointments, open communication, and availability for post-operative problems. Throughout the healing process, a kind and accommodating care staff can offer comfort and assistance, making sure that any problems are dealt with quickly and efficiently.

Financial Planning: The cost of the treatment and your insurance coverage are important factors to take into account because pacemaker surgery may be a major financial expenditure. Consult a financial counsellor or the billing department of the healthcare provider to discuss your choices for financial planning, estimate your possible out-of-pocket costs, and look into assistance programs or payment plans if necessary.

paragraphs: These methods will help you select the finest pacemaker surgery doctor who will match your demands and guarantee the best potential outcome for your treatment.
Recovery Process After Pacemaker Implantation Surgery

After pacemaker implantation surgery, most patients recover well and may return to their regular activities in a few days. Usually, patients stay in the hospital for monitoring and rehab after a pacemaker insertion procedure. Depending on a patient's unique circumstances and the intricacy of the treatment, the length of the hospital stay may change. However, joint pain and discomfort at the location of the incision can be controlled with medicine.

To ensure that the incision heals correctly, you must refrain from heavy lifting and intense activity during the first healing phase. In order to promote healing and general heart health, patients are encouraged to adhere to a recovery diet high in nutrients. Cut back on processed foods, saturated fats, and salt to preserve heart health and promote general well-being. When near strong electromagnetic field emitting devices, such as large magnets, MRI machines, and some electrical equipment, use caution. Seek advice from your medical team.

The cardiologist and surgeon will schedule routine follow-up sessions to assess the pacemaker's performance and make any required modifications. With the right aftercare and attention to post-operative guidelines, patients may anticipate a full recovery and enhanced quality of life following pacemaker implantation surgery.
Is a Pacemaker Safe?

Most patients find pacemaker implantation procedures to be safe and well-tolerated. However, it includes some risks and problems, such as bleeding, infection, or device malfunction, much like any surgical operation. Selecting a qualified surgeon and following instructions for post-operative care can help reduce these risks of heart Implantation and increase the likelihood of a favourable result.

Choosing the best surgeon for pacemaker installation surgery is an important choice that may significantly influence the outcome and long-term cardiac health. By taking into account variables including experience, expertise, and satisfaction with treatment, people may make well-informed decisions and ensure the best care possible throughout their treatment journey. Pacemaker surgery continues to provide valuable options for treating cardiac rhythm abnormalities and enhancing the quality of life because of surgical methods and post-operative care developments.

blogs.title: Cardiac Arrest: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment Options

paragraphs: Cardiac arrest refers to a sudden, unexpected loss of hearing function. Although it can be lethal, getting treatment as soon as possible can improve your prognosis.

Electrical impulses regulate the rhythm of the heartbeat. The heartbeat becomes irregular when the pattern of these impulses changes - also known as arrhythmia - whose intensity and severity might vary. In severe cases, arrhythmias can lead to cardiac arrest — a medical condition that might result in disability or death.

However, it must be noted that a heart attack is not the same as sudden cardiac arrest. When blood supply to a portion of the heart is restricted, a heart attack occurs, and cardiac arrest does not happen due to blockage. On the other hand, a heart attack may result in a shift in the electrical activity of the heart that triggers rapid cardiac arrest. The symptoms of cardiac arrest might range from no pulse to palpitations, no breathing, loss of consciousness, etc.
But it must also be noted that cardiac arrest sometimes shows no symptoms. So, seeing a doctor in case of minor discomfort is also advisable.

sections.heading: What Causes Cardiac Arrest?
paragraphs: Any changes in the heart’s electrical activity- which controls the rate and rhythm of the heart, can cause cardiac arrest. The most common cause of cardiac arrest is irregular heart rhythm, known as ventricular fibrillation. This reduces the effective blood pumping - instead, the lower heart chambers quiver ineffectively due to irregular and rapid cardiac signals.
list: Coronary Artery Disease - If the heart’s arteries fill with deposits of cholesterol and other materials, the heart’s blood flow may reduce and sudden cardiac arrest may occur.

Heart Attack - A heart attack can result in ventricular fibrillation and abrupt cardiac arrest. Heart attacks are frequently caused by severe coronary artery disease. Moreover, scar tissue after a heart attack may remain in the heart. The heartbeat may alter as a result of the scar tissue.
Heart Enlargement Known as Cardiomyopathy - This condition results from a strain in the heart muscle walls. The cardiac muscle thickens or grows larger.
Heart Valve Dysfunction - The heart muscle may expand or thicken due to leakage or narrowing of the heart valves.
Congenital Heart Defect - A congenital heart defect is the term for a cardiac condition existing from birth.
LQTS (long QT syndrome) and Other Cardiac Signalling issues - Heart arrhythmias are brought on by disorders including Brugada syndrome and extended QT syndrome.

sections.subheading: What are the Symptoms of Cardiac Arrest?
paragraphs: Cardiac arrest warning signs are frequently the early symptoms. Receiving medical attention before cardiac arrest may save your life.Here are the symptoms of cardiac arrest:
list: Grow lightheaded (dizziness)
Feel weak or exhausted
Shortness of breath
Vomiting
Palpitations

paragraphs: If you or someone you are with encounters these symptoms, you need to get emergency care right away:
list: No pulse
Chest discomfort
Unconsciousness and collapse
Respiratory difficulties or cessation of breathing

sections.heading: What are the Treatment Options for Cardiac Arrest?
paragraphs: It is essential to seek medical attention if you have any abnormal cardiac symptoms. To start an effective treatment process, doctors will perform specific tests, such as an electrocardiogram, to identify abnormalities in the patient's heart rhythm.
list: Blood tests - These tests can look for signs of a heart attack and measure magnesium and potassium levels in the blood.
Chest X-ray - They look for other signs of diseases in the heart. It shows the shape and size of the heart and if a patient has heart failure.
Nuclear Scan - This test is done with a stress test to see problems related to blood flow. A radioactive tracer is injected and tracked by a special camera.
Cardiac Catheterization - Helps visualize blockages in heart arteries using a flexible tube and contrast dye.
Echocardiogram - Uses sound waves to create images showing blood flow through the heart and its valves.

paragraphs: Several other tests may be done, which will be prescribed only if required, depending on your symptoms. The cardiology doctor will evaluate the diagnostic reports and create a treatment plan.

Generally, immediate treatment is required in cases of cardiac arrests, often before any diagnostic tests. First-line treatment includes Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) or Defibrillation, which helps reset heart rhythm.
Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR): Involves quick chest compressions in cases where the heartbeat has stopped. It is crucial even if you're not trained.
Defibrillation: Uses electric shock to reset abnormal heart rhythm. Most defibrillators use a biphasic waveform needing lower energy.
Here are some other treatment plans for cardiac arrest and related cardiac issues:
Medicines– The heart rhythm can be restored with anti-arrhythmic medications. Additional medications that may be used to treat or reduce the risk of sudden cardiac death include –
list: Beta-blockers
Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors
Calcium channel blockers

paragraphs: Surgeries– Surgeries might be necessary to open a blockage, treat heart rhythm problems, or place a device to ensure the heart functions properly. Here are some surgical processes involved –
list: Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillator (ICD) to detect and correct irregular heartbeats
Coronary Angioplasty to open blocked arteries
Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery (CABG) to restore blood flow
Radiofrequency Catheter Ablation to block faulty pathways in the heart
Corrective Heart Surgery to treat congenital defects

Radiofrequency Catheter Ablation is done to block a faulty pathway that might cause irregular heartbeats. One of the more flexible tubes, also known as a catheter, is threaded through the blood vessels to inside the heart, creating small scars in the heart and blocking irregular heart signals.
Corrective Heart Surgery is a treatment to correct congenital heart valve disease or heart muscle disease.

paragraphs: In addition to this treatment, doctors might also prescribe lifestyle changes such as:
list: Quit smoking
Reduce alcohol consumption
Eat a healthy diet (e.g., omega-rich foods, whole grains, low-fat dairy)

paragraphs: Cardiac arrest is a life-threatening condition marked by sudden loss of heart function. Symptoms include sudden collapse, loss of consciousness, and absence of pulse or breathing. Immediate treatment with CPR and defibrillation is critical for survival.

Lifestyle changes such as regular exercise, a healthy diet, and avoiding smoking can lower the risk. However, it’s paramount to consult a healthcare provider for personalized advice. Early detection and management significantly improve outcomes, emphasizing the importance of proactive healthcare in mitigating cardiac arrest risks.

blogs.title: Hypertension: The Silent Killer - Unveiling the Dangers and Protecting Your Health

sections.heading: Overview
paragraphs: Hypertension, or high blood pressure, is often called a “silent killer” because there are no obvious symptoms of this condition that may indicate that something is wrong. Thus, it may go unnoticed. When blood flows through the arteries, it puts some pressure against the walls of the arteries. Such pressure can fluctuate throughout the day. Pressure against the arterial wall crossing higher than normal levels may not show any obvious signs, and mounting pressure over time without treatment may lead to fatal complications.The best way to protect oneself against it is to understand the individual risks and take the necessary steps to ensure that blood pressure is under control.

sections.heading: Knowing Where You Stand: Blood Pressure Numbers
paragraphs: Blood pressure measurement refers to the force exerted by the flow of blood against the walls of the arteries every time the heart pumps the blood. The blood pressure of an individual is measured based on two readings that provide insight into their health.
list: The first reading, or top number, refers to the systolic pressure, which is the pressure in the blood vessels when the heart beats.
The second, or bottom number, is the diastolic pressure, which is when the heart relaxes between successive heartbeats and the pressure in the blood vessels is lower than systolic pressure.

subsections.paragraphs:
Blood Pressure CategorySystolic Pressure in mmHgand/orDiastolic Pressure in mmHg
Normal< 120and< 80
Elevated120–129and< 80
High Blood Pressure (Hypertension Stage 1)130–139or80–89
High Blood Pressure (Hypertension Stage 2)> 140or> 90
Hypertensive Crisis> 180or> 120

sections.subpara: Having a blood pressure significantly higher than the 120/80 mmHg mark is a cause for concern, and the person should consult a doctor to take appropriate steps.

paragraphs: The first number, or systolic pressure number, is higher than the second, or diastolic pressure number. Blood pressure is measured in mmHg. The normal blood pressure is represented by 120/80 mmHg and lower. Based on measurement of blood pressure, here is what it means at different levels.
Having a blood pressure significantly higher than the 120/80 mmHg mark is a cause for concern, and the person should consult a doctor to take appropriate steps.

sections.heading: What is Hypertension?
paragraphs: Hypertension, or high blood pressure, is the condition of having higher than normal blood pressure. Although a person's blood pressure may fluctuate throughout the day, a person with consistent high blood pressure measured at different times during the day may be diagnosed with high blood pressure. Higher the blood pressure, more is the risk of having other health conditions, affecting vital organs like the heart and the kidneys.

Doctors or healthcare professionals may measure a person's blood pressure and compare it against the set medical standards of normal blood pressure. Observing consistent high blood pressure can help healthcare providers diagnose high blood pressure and make treatment decisions by reviewing their overall health condition.
Significance of Knowing Your Blood Pressure

Early detection is key to preventing complications arising from hypertension. A person may have elevated or high blood pressure and not know it because the blood pressure increases gradually, and there are barely any symptoms. Hypertension, or high blood pressure, can be detected only through regular measurement of blood pressure in an individual. Having high blood pressure puts a person at risk of numerous cardiovascular conditions, and even stroke, among other ailments. Therefore, it is essential to keep measuring blood pressure at regular intervals if high blood pressure has been diagnosed, or if a person is at risk of developing hypertension.

sections.heading: Understanding the Risk Factors: What's Behind Hypertension?
paragraphs: High blood pressure usually develops over time and without any warning signs. A combination of physical and environmental factors may contribute to high blood pressure. Understanding the following risk factors can help prevent hypertension beforehand by taking preventive measures:
list: Family History: Having parents or close blood relatives with high blood pressure may put a person at an increased risk of hypertension.
Age: Older adults, usually over the age of 65, are more likely to suffer from hypertension due to degradation of their arterial elasticity.
Smoking and Tobacco Use: Using tobacco products can cause arterial damage by temporarily increasing blood pressure, often posing a risk of developing heart diseases.
Chronic Kidney Diseases: High blood pressure may result from kidney diseases. Furthermore, having high blood pressure further damages the kidney.
Diabetes: Having unregulated diabetes may also put a person at risk of hypertension.
Excessive Alcohol Consumption: Heavy alcohol consumption can put a person at risk of developing various health issues, including hypertension and even heart failure.

Sedentary Lifestyle: Consuming junk and highly salted foods, rich in calories with high saturated and trans fat and sugar can pose serious health issues, including high blood pressure. Additionally, not exercising or getting enough physical activity coupled with such dietary habits can put the blood vessels at risk of plaque accumulation, leading to hypertension.
Obesity: Being obese or greatly overweight can also put pressure on the heart and circulatory system, putting a person at risk of developing cardiovascular problems as well as hypertension.
High Cholesterol: Having high cholesterol levels is associated with hypertension.

Stress: Consistent stress can put pressure on the blood vessels, and lead people to resort to unhealthy coping mechanisms, such as consuming unhealthy foods, drinking, and smoking. Together, they pose great risk of developing hypertension.

sections.heading: Recognising Your Risks: Knowing the Signs & Symptoms of High Blood Pressure
paragraphs: Hypertension is hailed as the “silent killer” as it does not exhibit any warning signs or symptoms until it has gone too far and started damaging other parts of the body. Despite having consistent high blood pressure, people are not aware of it. Therefore, the only way to know if a person has hypertension is to measure their blood pressure at regular intervals.
Consequences of Hypertension: Be Mindful of the Health Risks
Hypertension can be damaging to health in a number of ways, and mostly affects the vital organs of the body, such as the heart, kidneys, eyes, and even the brain.

list: Cardiovascular Conditions: High blood pressure puts constant pressure on the arteries causing them to lose their elasticity, and decreasing the flow of blood and oxygen to the heart which may lead to various cardiovascular problems such as chest pain (angina), heart attack, and heart failure among others.

Brain Problems: Hypertension may damage the arteries supplying oxygen to the brain causing the arteries to become blocked and burst, leading to a stroke. This can lead to impairment and disabilities in speech, movement, and other activities. Having hypertension is also linked to poorer cognitive abilities and dementia later on in life.
Kidney Diseases: People with hypertension or diabetes, or both are at a higher risk of developing chronic kidney diseases.

paragraphs: Managing & Preventing High Blood Pressure

The good news is, it is possible to manage high blood pressure by lowering the risk of health problems and regulating hypertension through treatment. The first step towards treating and managing hypertension is to seek medical advice. A healthcare provider may recommend medicines to regulate high blood pressure.

When a person is diagnosed with hypertension, medicines alone may not be enough to keep it under control. Actively making lifestyle changes to lower blood pressure can also be immensely beneficial. Here's what one can do to manage and prevent high blood pressure.
list: Get at least 30 minutes of physical activity for at least 5 days in a week
Quit smoking
Obtain and maintain a healthy weight
Consume a healthy diet devoid of high sodium or salt and alcohol
Manage stress

paragraphs: It may also be useful to measure blood pressure regularly. Regular blood pressure measurement is not only important for keeping track of the hypertensive condition but also provides an insight into the effectiveness of treatment for high blood pressure.

High blood pressure tends to be a lifelong condition that often shows little to no symptoms. This may make it difficult to detect its presence or the effectiveness of medicines without regularly checking a person’s blood pressure. Therefore, it is important to understand the risk factors, and know if a person has any. This may help diagnose high blood pressure at the earliest and prevent it from worsening by taking preventive measures.

blogs.title: How Does Stress Contribute To Heart Disease Risk?

paragraphs: Feeling stressed? It's your body's normal response to challenging situations. When stressed, your brain makes hormones like cortisol and adrenaline. Cortisol provides energy by releasing sugar into your blood, and adrenaline prepares you for 'fight or flight' by revving up your heart rate, breathing, and blood flow, preparing you to handle and cope with the stress.Persistent stress can increase your risk for heart disease, high blood pressure (BP), diabetes, and unhealthy behaviours like poor eating habits. However, you can combat chronic stress through exercise, relaxation techniques, sleep, and social support. Don't let stress harm your health; instead, find healthy ways to manage it and keep your heart strong.

Living with constant stress can damage your heart. Several studies have revealed that chronic stress may amplify your odds of getting cardiovascular disease, coronary heart disease, stroke, and even death. It may also promote cardiomyopathy, which weakens the heart muscle.

Research shows prolonged stress is tied to poor heart health in several ways - major life events, workplace stress, loneliness, or childhood trauma, etc. When you're stressed, your body churns out hormones like cortisol and adrenaline over and over. It leads to inflammation in arteries, raising the risk of heart attacks and strokes.

Studies show that when you’re stressed for a long time, it activates your amygdala. That’s the part of your brain that controls emotions and fear. A stressed amygdala is linked to inflammation in your arteries, which is not good for you. This artery inflammation increases your risk of a heart attack, stroke, and other scary cardiovascular problems. Stress causes a surge of hormones like cortisol, and these hormones make your bone marrow produce more white blood cells, which creates damaging inflammation in the arteries.

sections.subheading: Stress Worsens Other Heart Risk Factors
paragraphs: Stress doesn't just directly harm your arteries - it also worsens other risk factors for heart disease. Studies show prolonged stress contributes to high blood pressure and diabetes, two major risk factors for the heart.

When you're stressed, your body pumps out stress hormones like cortisol. This can result in developing high blood pressure. Stress also triggers the release of glucose into your bloodstream, raising your risk for diabetes.

In addition, stress often impacts heart-healthy behaviours. People struggling with high stress levels tend to exercise less and reach for unhealthy comfort foods that pack on pounds. They may drink more alcohol to unwind, light up cigarettes to calm down, or skip taking important heart medications.
Stress even impacts what you choose to eat. Research reveals high stress is linked to making less nutritious food choices and weight gain.

sections.subheading: Managing Stress to Protect Your Heart
paragraphs: You can't avoid all stress, but you can take steps to lower your stress levels and protect your heart. The good news is there are many effective stress-busting techniques that can help you manage stress.
list: Regular exercise: Regular exercise is definitely a good thing for heart health and stress relief. Aim for 30 minutes of activity on most days, or whatever feels right for you. Try to take a brisk walk, try a yoga class to stretch it out, or dance around to fun music. Finding movement you enjoy is key to keeping your heart safe and healthy.

Relaxation techniques: Relaxation techniques also lower blood pressure and make you feel more calm. Try deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, guided meditation apps, mindfulness, and tai chi. You can also explore different options to see what suits you the best. Just around 5 to 10 minutes a day can make a huge difference in your life.

Hobbies and fun activities: Hobbies and fun activities are another easy way to beat stress. You could always read a good book, watch a comedy special, play with your pet, or dive into a craft project - do whatever boosts your mood.

Support group: Connecting with supportive friends and family helps you feel less alone. But if you can't meet in person, stay in touch via text, phone calls, or video chats. Having people to share laughs makes a difference.
Adequate sleep: Prioritising restful sleep prevents fatigue from worsening stress. Aim for 7-9 hours per night by sticking to a bedtime routine that preps your body and mind for sleep.

Counselling: If self-care isn't enough, talk to your doctor about counselling, support groups, or online therapy for extra help. Remember, you’re not alone in this journey; there are people to support you.
sections.subpara: The key is trying different techniques to build a toolbox that works for you. By keeping chronic stress in check, you protect your heart and overall well being.

paragraphs: Stress prepares your body to handle threats. However, chronic stress boosts your risk for heart disease and related events like stroke. Recent research shows links between stress, brain activity, and inflammatory artery changes. Along with worsening other risk factors like high blood pressure, stress also promotes unhealthy behaviours. Therefore, it is important to focus on stress-busting self-care to enhance your overall health and keep your heart strong.

blogs.title: 8 Things You Can Do to Prevent Heart Disease and Stroke

paragraphs: The main causes of death globally are heart disease, heart attacks, and strokes. However, there is also good news: cardiovascular disease can be prevented in about 80% of instances. While certain risk factors, such as family history, gender, or age, cannot be changed, there are several approaches to minimise one's risk of heart disease. By altering one's lifestyle, especially by incorporating certain basic and uncomplicated tasks, one can significantly reduce the risk.
Let's get started with these eight recommendations for improving heart health:
Avoid the consumption of tobacco or smoking

The best thing a person can do for their heart is to stop smoking or using cigarettes. Even if someone is not a smoker, they should make sure to avoid second-hand smoke. Tobacco's chemical components can harm the heart and blood arteries in several different ways. Smoking hastens the production of clots and, in addition to making the blood thicker, it makes it more difficult for the arteries to accumulate plaque. Smoking causes the heart to work harder to pump adequate oxygen to the body and brain, leading to a drop in the blood's oxygen paragraphs, which raises blood pressure and heart rate.

Within a day of quitting, the risk of developing heart disease begins to decline. After a year of quitting smoking, the risk of heart disease is roughly halved. The benefits of quitting smoking start right away, regardless of how much or how long someone has smoked.

The risk of heart disease can be reduced by engaging in regular, everyday physical exercise. Exercise also makes weight management easier and lessens the likelihood of developing additional diseases, including type 2 diabetes, high blood pressure, and high cholesterol, all of which can strain the heart. Devoting at least five days a week to moderate exercise is recommended. Every morning after breakfast, start by going for a stroll around the neighbourhood. While one doesn't need to work out vigorously to reap the benefits, increasing the intensity, duration, and frequency of exercises will result in greater rewards.

A nutritious diet can lower the risk of type 2 diabetes, reduce blood pressure, and improve blood sugar and cholesterol levels. The most effective diet for avoiding heart disease is one that includes plenty of fruits and vegetables, fish, eggs, whole grains, nuts, and vegetable oils, while cutting back on red and processed meats, refined carbs, foods, and beverages with added sugar and salt.
The following food products should be consumed in smaller quantities:
list: Salt
Sugar
Alcohol
Processed carbs
Saturated fats

paragraphs: Try to reduce Blood pressure

High blood pressure is a key risk factor for stroke and can significantly increase the likelihood of experiencing one. The primary risk indicator for stroke in both men and women is a high blood pressure reading. Monitoring blood pressure and effectively managing it if it is high are likely to have a major positive impact on the condition of the vascular system. The ideal target to strive for is a blood pressure reading of less than 120/80. Some individuals could benefit more from a slightly less demanding target, such as 140/90 or lower.

Heart disease risk is increased by being overweight, especially in the central region of the body. High blood pressure, high cholesterol, and type 2 diabetes are just a few of the problems that can be triggered by excess weight, raising the risk of developing heart disease. The body mass index (BMI), determined using a person's height and weight, can classify whether they are overweight or obese. A BMI of 25 or higher is considered overweight and is often linked to elevated blood pressure, cholesterol levels, and an increased risk of heart disease and stroke.

Even a slight weight loss can be beneficial. Just a small amount of weight loss can help lower levels of certain blood fats (triglycerides), and reduce the risk of type 2 diabetes and high blood sugar. Further weight loss can also contribute to lowered cholesterol and blood pressure.

Lack of sleep increases the risk of obesity, heart attacks, high blood pressure, diabetes, and depression in individuals. Typically, adults require at least seven hours of sleep every night. By going to bed and getting up at the same time each day, one can establish a consistent sleep pattern and adhere to it. If a person feels like they are getting adequate sleep but still experiences fatigue throughout the day, they should consult a doctor. The physician will assess for obstructive sleep apnea, a condition that can elevate the risk of heart disease. Two potential treatments for obstructive sleep apnea are using a continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) device to keep the airway open during sleep and reducing weight.

The heart and blood arteries can be affected by high blood pressure and high cholesterol levels. However, one is unlikely to be able to tell if they have these problems without getting tested for them. Regular screening can provide numerical values and indicate whether any actions are required. As early as the age of 18, blood pressure should be checked for signs of high blood pressure, a risk factor for heart disease and stroke. Blood pressure should be checked at least twice every two years. Additionally, adults should have their cholesterol levels checked at least once every four to six years. While the average age for starting cholesterol testing is 20, earlier testing may be recommended if a person has additional risk factors, such as a family history of heart disease.

Everyone is impacted by stress in a different manner. Some people resort to harmful coping mechanisms, including binge eating, excessive drinking, or smoking, to deal with stress. Lack of sleep, pain, and headaches are all symptoms of stress that can wear down the body. The heart may have to work harder when there is ongoing stress. Any additional heart disease risk factors will worsen as a result. Finding alternative means of stress management, such as exercise, breathing practices, or meditation, can contribute to one’s overall health.

blogs.title: Raise Low Blood Pressure Naturally Through Diet

paragraphs: Low blood pressure, often known as hypotension, is defined as a blood pressure measurement less than 90/60 mm Hg. This medical condition affects a large number of individuals, especially as they get older. Low blood pressure can be triggered by a number of causes, including adverse reactions to medications and medical conditions such as diabetes. If there are no symptoms, low blood pressure is not worrisome. Most medical professionals will only identify low blood pressure as a cause for concern if a patient exhibits its symptoms, such as blurred vision, dizziness, and fainting. Low blood pressure can lead to a heart attack or stroke, both of which might be fatal or result in long-term harm to the brain and heart.

sections.heading: Risks of Low Blood Pressure
paragraphs: Many people don't notice low blood pressure, but it can lead to some extremely serious issues if it goes untreated. A blood pressure reading that is too low can result in:
list: Blurry vision
Nausea
Headaches
Heart palpitations

paragraphs: Continuous drops in blood pressure indicate a medical emergency. When your blood pressure is extremely low, your important organs are deprived of oxygen, potentially leading to shock.

What we eat may significantly influence our blood pressure, similar to its impact on numerous other medical conditions. Here are a few dietary recommendations that could help raise blood pressure back up to a healthy level.

sections.heading: Here are foods to eat to raise low blood pressure

paragraphs: When it comes to raising and maintaining a normal blood pressure, staying hydrated can be highly beneficial. Our bodies lose water when we're dehydrated, decreasing blood volume and blood pressure. Most medical professionals recommend consuming at least two litres of water daily. It's advisable to increase water intake during hot weather or when working out.

Our blood pressure could rise if you consume a lot of salty foods. The sodium in salt causes our bodies to retain more water to 'wash' it out of the system when we consume large amounts of it. Cottage cheese, olives, and canned soup are all excellent sources of salt. Depending on personal preference, one may season the food with either table salt or sea salt. When added to a balanced diet, a little additional salt may be helpful for those with low blood pressure. Nevertheless, it's important to remember that consistently excessive salt intake can seriously affect health.

Caffeinated beverages, such as coffee and caffeinated tea, can lead to an increase in heart rate and a sudden rise in blood pressure, especially in individuals who are not accustomed to consuming them. This effect is usually temporary, as caffeine's impact on blood pressure varies from person to person. Caffeine is present in a variety of foods and beverages, including coffee, tea, cocoa, chocolate, and others.

Folate, also known as Vitamin B9, is abundant in foods like broccoli, spinach, oranges, eggs, lentils, and chickpeas. Our body requires folate to support cell division, leading to the production of more red blood cells, thus preventing severe anaemia. A deficiency in folate can result in anaemia, which in turn can lead to decreased blood pressure. Furthermore, the symptoms of folate deficiency overlap with those of a vitamin B12 deficiency.

Vitamin B12 is essential for the production of healthy red blood cells and the prevention of megaloblastic anaemia, a blood disorder that leads to fatigue and weakness. Insufficient levels of this crucial vitamin can result in anaemia, which not only reduces blood pressure but also leads to excessive bleeding while potentially damaging organs and nerves. Anaemia further contributes to decreased blood pressure. Foods rich in vitamin B12 include eggs, poultry, fish, and low-fat dairy products.

Tulsi leaves serve as a valuable source of vitamin C and are abundant in antioxidants. Chewing 4-5 holy basil leaves in the morning can help lower blood pressure. This is due to Tulsi's high paragraphs of potassium and magnesium, both of which promote healthy blood flow.

Although drinking alcohol can increase blood pressure, it can also cause the body to become dehydrated, which reduces blood pressure by lowering the volume of your blood. Alcohol should never be used as a means of treating low blood pressure, and one should refrain from consuming large amounts of it. To prevent dehydration, make an effort to drink a glass of water after each alcoholic beverage. Along with many other negative impacts on your physical and emotional health, it can lead to hypertension (high blood pressure) in individuals with low blood pressure.

It takes a lot more energy for our bodies to digest a heavy meal, which might cause our blood pressure to drop. Since skipping meals usually results in overeating later to make up for it, this is a problem that affects intermittent fasters and those who skip breakfast, in particular. Having more frequent, smaller meals throughout the day is better for blood flow and digestion, even if one is not reducing overall calorie intake.

Foods heavy in carbohydrates, especially processed ones, tend to digest much more quickly than other foods, potentially leading to a sudden decrease in blood pressure. Several trials have shown that a low-carb diet can help counteract hypotension, especially in older individuals. To manage this, it's advised to limit carbohydrate-rich foods such as bread, pasta, potatoes, and rice.
In addition to dietary modifications, blood pressure can be raised through lifestyle changes. Here are some strategies to consider:
list: Take regular breaks while exercising outdoors in the heat, and make an extra effort to stay hydrated.
Gradually change your body's posture, such as by standing up periodically.
Avoid prolonged periods of bed rest.
Wear compression stockings that promote blood flow from the feet and legs upward.

paragraphs: If anyone experiences concerns about low blood pressure symptoms, they should consult their doctor. Likewise, medical professionals can assess the adverse effects of medications and make changes as necessary.

blogs.title: High Blood Pressure (Hypertension) - Symptoms & Causes

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: Hypertension is a condition of high blood pressure that affects the arteries of the body, where the blood flowing in the blood vessels exerts pressure on the walls of the arteries. This causes the heart to work extra hard to pump blood due to the consistent pressure on the arterial walls. Consequently, this deteriorates the arterial capacity over time, leading to serious health conditions such as heart attacks and strokes.

High blood pressure usually does not have any symptoms, so affected individuals may not realise they have a high blood pressure condition. There are many risk factors that increase the likelihood of developing hypertension. Making lifestyle adjustments and taking specific medications can be beneficial in reducing and managing high blood pressure or hypertension.

sections.heading: What is High Blood Pressure (Hypertension)?
paragraphs: High blood pressure or hypertension occurs when blood consistently exerts pressure on the walls of the arteries, causing damage over time. High blood pressure can make it harder for the heart to pump blood, potentially leading to various health complications in affected individuals, including heart attacks and strokes. Since it often presents no symptoms, it can remain undetected for a prolonged period, causing significant damage in the meantime.

Blood pressure is measured in millimetres of mercury (mmHg) and is indicated by systolic and diastolic values. Hypertension is typically diagnosed when the systolic pressure is at least 130 mmHg and the diastolic pressure is at least 90 mmHg. Individuals with blood pressure readings exceeding these values are considered to have hypertension. Blood pressure stages are categorised as follows:
list: Normal blood pressure: 120/80 or below
Elevated blood pressure: 120-129/80-89
High blood pressure: 130/80 or higher

paragraphs: Most people with hypertension may show no symptoms at all, even if they have a dangerously high blood pressure level. That's why it is also called the "silent killer." Usually, when the blood pressure level goes beyond 180/120, people may experience some symptoms such as:
list: Headaches
Nosebleeds
Shortness of breath
Palpitations

sections.heading: Types of High BP
paragraphs: High blood pressure can be categorized into two types:
list: Primary Hypertension: This type tends to develop over many years with no identifiable cause of high blood pressure. It is the most common type of hypertension and is often caused by lifestyle factors.

Secondary Hypertension: Secondary hypertension may be caused by an underlying health condition or certain medications. It can occur suddenly and coexist with primary hypertension. There are other types of high blood pressure conditions that can occur in specific situations or conditions, such as:
White Coat Hypertension
Masked Hypertension
Sustained Hypertension
Nocturnal Hypertension

paragraphs: Causes of High Blood Pressure
Primary hypertension does not have any distinct causes; rather, a combination of factors can cause such a condition over time. Some of the common causes of primary hypertension may include:
list: Dietary choices, especially the intake of sodium-rich foods.
High alcohol consumption.
Lack of physical activity.

paragraphs: On the other hand, the cause of secondary hypertension may be attributed to one or more conditions. Some of the common conditions that can lead to secondary hypertension may include:
list: Thyroid problems.
Kidney diseases, including renal vascular diseases that affect the blood flow in the arteries and veins of the kidneys.
Adrenal gland problems like tumours.
Obstructive sleep apnea.
Tobacco use.
Congenital vascular defects.
Prescription drugs: immunosuppressants, NSAIDs, pain relievers, birth control pills.
Illicit drugs.

paragraphs: Risk Factors
There are many risk factors when it comes to developing high blood pressure conditions. These may include the following:
list: Being over 55 years of age.
Being overweight.
Having a family history of cardiovascular diseases, high blood pressure, or diabetes.
Consuming foods rich in sodium (especially salty foods).
Having a low potassium level (due to diet or certain health conditions such as dehydration).
Lack of physical activity and exercise.
Using tobacco through chewing, smoking, or vaping.
Excessive alcohol intake.
Stress.
Pregnancy.
Certain chronic conditions, including metabolic syndrome.
Obstructive sleep apnea

paragraphs: Complications of High Blood Pressure

The excessive pressure on the walls of the blood vessels in organs can cause damage to both the vessels and the body's organs. Unless treated, high blood pressure can result in long-term damage, including an increased risk of health conditions such as:
list: Heart attack or stroke
Heart failure
Aneurysm
Peripheral artery disease
Kidney diseases, including kidney failure
Eye problems, including loss of vision
Vascular dementia
Pregnancy complications
Metabolic syndrome

paragraphs: Diagnosis & Treatment of High Blood Pressure

A blood pressure measuring device can help determine the blood pressure of an individual at any given point in time during a state of rest or activity, which can assist in measuring systolic and diastolic pressure in the arteries. It will provide a reading indicating the blood pressure, which doctors can then use to determine a course of treatment.
For borderline hypertension, doctors may recommend lifestyle changes to improve the condition. Recommendations may include the following:
list: Avoiding salty or sodium-rich foods
Maintaining a healthy body weight
Exercising regularly or getting enough physical activity
Avoiding smoking, chewing tobacco, vaping, and drinking alcohol
Getting sufficient sleep
subpara: If, despite making lifestyle changes, hypertension conditions do not improve, doctors may recommend certain medicines to lower blood pressure. These may include diuretics, ACE inhibitors, alpha/alpha-beta/beta blockers, etc. Blood pressure-regulating medications should only be taken upon the recommendation of a professional healthcare provider. Special care should be taken to ensure the correct dosage and the routine timing of taking the medications.

paragraphs: Prevention of High Blood Pressure
There are several ways to reduce and prevent the risk of high blood pressure, including:
list: Following a healthy diet plan by incorporating whole grains, fruits, and vegetables into your diet.
Minimising sodium and salt intake as much as possible.
Staying active and managing weight by shedding excess pounds to lower blood pressure.
Drinking alcohol in moderation and avoiding smoking since smoking almost instantly raises blood pressure.

blogs.title: Recognizing the Warning Signs: Symptoms of a Heart Attack
blogs.author: Omni Hospitals

paragraphs: When the blood flow to the heart is reduced or blocked, the blockage is usually caused due to fat buildup, cholesterol, and other factors. These buildups or deposits are called plaque, and the process of plaque buildup is called atherosclerosis. Sometimes, the plaque can form a clot that blocks or reduces the blood flow, which destroys the heart muscle. When there is little to no blood flow, the heart muscle begins to die, causing difficulty in breathing, chest pain, etc. It is important to understand the signs of heart attack, as it can save a person’s life. In this blog, we have discussed the symptoms and causes of a heart attack in detail.
Definition and causes of a heart attack

A heart attack is also called myocardial infarction. This occurs when fatty deposits in the arteries restrict the blood flow to the heart. A person experiencing a heart attack will feel pain in the chest and other parts of their body. It is important to note that a heart attack is different from cardiac arrest because, in cardiac arrest, the heart completely stops. On the other hand, a heart attack occurs from coronary artery disease when the blood does not flow properly, which can be life-threatening. This can be caused due to the following:
list: Coronary artery spasm
Unusual narrowing of blood vessels
Blood clot or air bubble trapped in the coronary artery
Tears or ruptures in the coronary artery
Electrolyte imbalance
Eating disorder
subpara: In addition, a heart attack is also caused by drug overuse.

paragraphs: Common risk factors for heart attacks
According to the American Heart Association, the following are common risk factors for a heart attack:
list: Male sex
Old age
Smoking
High blood pressure
High cholesterol levels
Low activity levels
High alcohol consumption
Higher level of stress
Consumption of processed food, along with added fat, sugar, etc.
Diabetes
Obesity
Genetics and family history
subpara: It is also said that a heart attack occurs when two or more factors combine. Moreover, people with a history of cardiovascular disease have a higher risk of a heart attack

subsections.heading: Typical symptoms of a heart attack
paragraphs: Heart attacks can have several symptoms. The symptoms and causes in men are different from women. Some of the common signs of heart attack are as follows:
list: Chest pain or discomfort
Shortness of breath
Pain or discomfort in other areas of the upper body
Nausea and vomiting
Feeling lightheaded and dizzy
Coughing and wheezing (when fluid builds up in the lungs)
Feeling tired and sweaty with slight movement
Feeling anxiety similar to a panic attack

paragraphs: Recognizing atypical or silent heart attacks
Symptoms in women
list: Chest pain and discomfort around the chest area.
Neck pain and upper back pain.
Indigestion.
Fatigue.
Dizziness.
Palpitations (fluttering feeling in the chest).

paragraphs: Symptoms in older adults
list: Shortness of breath.
Pain in the neck, arms, or jaw.
Nausea and an upset stomach.
Fatigue.

paragraphs: Silent heart attacks
list: Difficulty breathing.
Nausea and cold sweats.
Chest pain, fullness, and discomfort.
Discomfort in other areas of the body.

subsections.heading: Immediate response and emergency medical care
paragraphs: Calling emergency services
list: Call emergency health services immediately if someone starts experiencing signs of heart attack.

If you are the victim of a heart attack and cannot get an ambulance or emergency vehicle to come to you, ask a neighbour or friend to drive you to the nearest Best Cardiology Hospital in Hyderabad. Never drive by yourself. Driving alone puts you and others in danger since your condition could worsen.

paragraphs: Administering aspirin if advised by healthcare professionals
list: Aspirin helps blood flow normally by correcting blood clots. It may help decrease the damage caused by a heart attack, but it is essential to seek emergency medical assistance before taking the medication.

A low dose of aspirin may be sufficient to prevent or delay the formation of a blood clot, as aspirin is an effective blood thinner. However, if you are allergic to aspirin, you should avoid taking it.

paragraphs: Performing Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR) if necessary
list: Put your hands together in a fist lock and place the palms of your hands on the middle of the person's chest.
With your elbows locked and your shoulders above your hands, push quickly and forcefully at a rate of 100–120 compressions per minute. Press to a depth of about two inches.
Keep doing these compressions until the individual begins to breathe or move, until someone else takes over, or until you are worn out.
Try to alternate without stopping the compressions.

paragraphs: Individuals with existing heart conditions

People with heart conditions, such as Coronary Heart Disease (CHD), have a higher risk of experiencing a heart attack. In CHD, the blood vessels that supply blood to the heart get blocked by cholesterol deposits, also known as plaque.
Individuals with diabetes

Individuals with diabetes have a higher chance of developing high blood pressure and high cholesterol, which can lead to a heart attack. High blood sugar can damage the blood vessels of the heart and the surrounding nerves, potentially causing the blood vessels to rupture and form blood clots.
Individuals with a family history of heart disease

People with a family history of heart attacks are more likely to be at risk of experiencing a heart attack. However, it's essential to understand that having a family member who had a heart attack does not guarantee that you will also have one. Both genetics and lifestyle factors contribute to the development of this condition.
Lifestyle modifications for heart health
Living a healthy lifestyle is crucial for a healthy heart. Here are a few lifestyle modifications that you can make for healthy living:
list: Exercise daily for at least an hour.
Maintain a healthy weight.
Quit smoking.
Eat nutritious food.
Manage stress.

paragraphs: Regular check-ups and screenings

The heart and blood arteries can be harmed by excessive blood pressure and high cholesterol. Without testing, a person won’t likely be able to tell if they have these disorders. Thus, it is crucial to understand the need for getting regular checkups and screenings to ensure these conditions are addressed before they become life hazards. These checkups and screenings consist of:
list: Type 2 diabetes screening
Cholesterol level testing
Blood pressure measurement

paragraphs: Medication adherence and management of underlying conditions

It is crucial to take medication for underlying conditions that can cause a heart attack. It is advisable to take hypertension, cholesterol, and diabetes medications on time, while also implementing preventive measures to control these conditions. Proper management of these conditions helps in reducing the symptoms and minimising the risk of a heart stroke.

A heart attack is caused due to a blockage in the coronary artery. The blockage is caused by plaque deposits that rupture due to pressure in the blood flow, leading to blood clots. Underlying diseases such as diabetes, high cholesterol, and high blood pressure can lead to heart failure. It can be life-threatening and thus requires immediate care.

It is advisable to manage these conditions and adopt healthy lifestyle changes to lower the risk of heart attacks. Seek medical help at the earliest. blogs.title: Heart Disease More Than Heart Attacks
blogs.medically_reviewed_by: Cardiology Team at Omni Hospitals

paragraphs: There are many heart diseases with unique symptoms, treatments, and procedures. Although heart attacks is the most common known heart disease or condition, it is important to know the various heart diseases and their symptoms so as to stay vigilant and cautious. For some kind of heart diseases, simple lifestyle changes and proper medication helps but for others, different care and needs arise. When people talk about heart disease, heart attack or cardiac arrest is the only one that comes to mind. But there are many heart conditions other than heart attack.

sections.heading: Here are the heart diseases and conditions other than heart attack:
paragraphs: CAD (Coronary Artery Disease) is the most common heart condition that causes blockages in coronary arteries. CAD leads to uneven or decreased blood flow to the heart muscles and closes the way to receive the oxygen. This condition arises as a result of artery stiffening.
Coronary heart disease can cause chest pain, known as angina, or it can lead to a heart attack.
Some factors that may increase your risk of coronary artery disease include:
list: Age (The risk of heart disease increases after the age of 55 for males and substantially after menopause for women.)
Inactive lifestyle
Diabetes or the metabolic syndrome

paragraphs: When you have an arrhythmia, your heart beats at an erratic rate. Serious arrhythmias are frequently caused by other heart issues, although they can occasionally occur on their own.

sections.heading: Heart Failure
paragraphs: Heart failure occurs when your heart does not pump blood as efficiently as it should to meet your body’s needs. It is typically caused by coronary artery disease, although it can also occur as a result of thyroid illness, excessive blood pressure, heart muscle disease (cardiomyopathy), or other disorders.

An irregularity in the blood flow between the 4 chambers of heart, lungs, and blood vessels may make it difficult for a valve to open and close properly. When this happens, your blood flow may be obstructed or blood may leak. Your valve might not open and close properly.

sections.heading: Heart valve diseases include the following:
paragraphs: This is a bacterial infection that can enter the bloodstream and take root in your heart through illness, surgery, or the use of intravenous medicines. It frequently occurs if you already have valve issues. Antibiotics may typically heal it, but the condition is fatal if not treated.
If your heart valves have been severely damaged by endocarditis, you may require valve replacement surgery.
This illness occurs when rheumatic fever, which is connected to strep throat and scarlet fever, damages your heart muscle and valves.

Rheumatic heart disease was more widespread in the early twentieth century. Doctors can now avoid it by treating the disorders that cause it with antibiotics. If you do contract it, the symptoms usually appear years after the infection.

Pericardial disease or inflammation of pericardium is caused by viral infection. It is an inflammatory disorder that damages the sac that covers and surrounds your heart. Pericardial damage leads one to undergo open heart surgery.
Cardiomyopathy is a condition that affects the heart muscle. When your heart muscle contracts, stretches, and stiffens, it doesn’t pump blood regularly and disrupts the heart functioning.
Although there are many reasons or situations leading to this condition, cardiac abnormalities caused by genes, toxic reactions, and infections stand to be some of the common causes.

sections.heading: Congenital Heart Defect
paragraphs: When something goes wrong when a baby’s heart is still forming in the womb, this is known as congenital heart disease. Sometimes the heart defect creates problems right away, but other times it doesn’t produce problems until you’re an adult.
One of the most common congenital heart problems is septal anomaly. These are the gaps in the wall that separates the left and right portions of your heart.
Pulmonary stenosis is another sort of defect. A narrow valve reduces the flow of blood to your lungs. The valve can be opened or replaced through a procedure or surgery.

A tiny blood channel known as the ductus arteriosus does not close properly at birth in certain newborns. When this occurs, blood flows back into the pulmonary artery, putting strain on your heart. Doctors can treat this with surgery, a procedure, or medication in some cases.

blogs.title: Heart Problems, Diagnosis & Treatment
blogs.medically_reviewed_by: Cardiology Team at Omni Hospitals

paragraphs: A condition that affects the heart's structure or function is considered heart disease. People often refer to heart disease as one condition. Heart disease, however, is an umbrella term for several conditions.
Let’s understand different heart diseases:

sections.heading: Coronary artery disease
paragraphs: What: More than 10 million people are diagnosed with Coronary artery every year in India. This happens when the major blood vessels of the heart are damaged or diseased. Plaque build-up causes this condition. It restricts blood flow to the heart by narrowing coronary arteries.
Symptoms: Symptoms of coronary artery disease are diverse and can range from no symptoms to chest pain to heart attack.
Treatment: Treatment options include lifestyle changes, medication, angioplasty, and surgery.
What: Happens because of the irregular beating of the heart. When the heart’s electrical impulses do not function properly, the condition is called cardiac arrhythmia.
Symptoms: It may not show any symptoms. However, fluttering in the chest, chest pain, dizziness, and fainting can be seen because of this condition.
Treatment: The treatment may involve anti-arrhythmic drugs, medical procedures, implants, and surgery, as needed.
What: It refers to a defect within the heart’s walls, valves, or chambers. It can either be congenital (present at birth) or develop over time.

Causes: Having high blood pressure, atherosclerosis, taking certain medications, having a previous heart attack, rheumatic fever, endocarditis, cardiomyopathy, or having certain other infections increases your risk of structural heart disease.

Treatment: There are several minimally invasive procedures available to treat structural heart disease, depending on the situation. Transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR), alcohol septal ablation, mitral clip, and Amplatzer septal occluder are among the treatments.
What: Heart failure is a chronic condition that causes the heart to pump blood poorly. Insufficient pumping or filling can lead to heart failure (systolic or diastolic).
Symptoms: Shortness of breath, fatigue, swelling of the legs, and a rapid heartbeat are some symptoms.
Treatment: The treatment may include reducing salt intake, limiting fluid consumption, and taking prescription medications. A pacemaker or defibrillator may be implanted sometimes.

sections.heading: Risk factors for heart diseases
paragraphs: Cardiovascular disease is largely caused by high blood pressure, high cholesterol, and smoking. Other conditions and lifestyle choices can also put people at risk for heart disease, including:
list: Having diabetes
Being overweight
Eating an unhealthy diet
Lack of physical activity
Excessive alcohol consumption

paragraphs: Different tests are available for diagnosing heart disease. The doctor will begin by taking your personal and family medical history, recording current and past symptoms, and doing laboratory tests. Further tests may be ordered based on the results of the assessment and tests.
There are some tests that are non-invasive, meaning no instruments are inserted into the body. However, there are others that are invasive and require the insertion of instruments.
Different diagnosis methods include:
Laboratory Tests- Blood tests
list: Lipid profile
Lipoprotein (a)
C-reactive protein (CRP)
Homocysteine
Complete blood count (CBC)
Fasting glucose

paragraphs: Non-Invasive Tests
list: Electrocardiogram
Echocardiogram
Stress EKG
Nuclear Stress Test
Carotid Ultrasound
Abdominal Ultrasound
Holter Monitor
Event Recorder

paragraphs: Invasive Tests
list: Cardiac Catheterization and Coronary Angiography
Electrophysiology Study

paragraphs: The severity and condition of heart disease determine how the disease is treated. While lifestyle changes can be helpful in one kind of heart condition, other condition may require an implantable device, such as a pacemaker. Your doctor will determine the best treatment plan for your situation. Ensure that you follow their instructions carefully and completely.
Treatment for heart disease can include:
Heart disease management often begins with lifestyle modifications. A heart-healthy lifestyle includes eating a low-fat, low-sodium diet, exercising regularly, and quitting smoking.
Medications may be prescribed when lifestyle changes do not cure heart disease. The type of medication prescribed is determined by the severity of the condition.

Sometimes, surgery is required when lifestyle changes and medication are not sufficient. Depending on the type of heart disease and the amount of damage to your heart, your doctor may recommend a different procedure.

blogs.title: Cardiac arrest in Youngsters – Causes & Prevention
blogs.medically_reviewed_by: Cardiology Team at Omni Hospitals

sections.heading: Cardiac Arrest
paragraphs: Heart defects or other heart abnormalities that are overlooked or undiscovered often cause sudden death in people younger than 35. Usually, sudden deaths like these occur while performing physical activity, such as playing sports. Males die more often than females because of SCA. Many elementary, high school, and college athletes take part without incident every year. Talk to your doctor if you or your child are at risk of sudden death so that you can take precautions.

If not treated within minutes, Sudden Cardiac Arrest (SCA) can cause death. The condition results from an “unexpected loss of heart function” that causes loss of consciousness and collapse. Surviving outside a hospital depends on prompt emergency responses by bystanders.

sections.subheading: What are the causes of sudden cardiac arrest in youngsters and how can we prevent it?
sections.heading: Cardiac Arrest Causes:
paragraphs: Sudden cardiac arrest is most often caused by an abnormal heart rhythm (arrhythmia). When your heart’s electrical system isn’t functioning correctly, sudden cardiac arrest can occur. The electrical system controls heart rate and rhythm in the heart. Something wrong with your heart causes an irregular heartbeat (arrhythmia). Most types of arrhythmia are temporary and harmless; however, some types can cause sudden cardiac arrest. Heart arrhythmias in the lower chamber of the heart (ventricle) are the most common at the time of cardiac arrest. The ventricles (ventricular fibrillation) quiver uselessly when you receive rapid, erratic electrical signals.

sections.subheading: Sudden cardiac death occurs for a variety of reasons in young people, including:

sections.heading: People with no known heart disease can experience sudden cardiac arrest. In most cases, a life-threatening arrhythmia occurs in a person with an undiagnosed, pre-existing heart condition. The following are some possibilities:
list: Heart attack - A heart attack can cause ventricular fibrillation and sudden cardiac arrest, often because of severe coronary disease. It can also result in scarring in your heart. Your heart rhythm may be abnormal if electrical short circuits are surrounding the scar tissue.

Congenital heart disease - Congenital heart disease may cause sudden cardiac arrest in children or adolescents. SCA still occurs in adults with congenital heart defects who have undergone corrective surgery.

Coronary artery disease - People who have coronary artery disease are more likely to suffer sudden cardiac arrest, in which the arteries become clogged with cholesterol and other deposits, reducing blood flow to the heart.
Heart enlargement (cardiomyopathy) - It’s caused by your heart’s muscular walls stretching and enlarging or thickening. In that case, your heart muscle is abnormal, leading to arrhythmias.

Heart electrical problems - An electrical problem may occur in some people rather than a problem with the heart muscle or valves. Among these are conditions such as Brugada syndrome and long QT syndrome, which are categorized as primary heart rhythm abnormalities.

Valve-based heart disease - You may experience stretching or thickening of your heart muscle because of leakage or narrowing of your heart valves. An arrhythmia is more likely to occur when the chambers are enlarged or weakened because of a tight or leaking valve.

paragraphs: You can reduce your risk by following your doctor's orders, making lifestyle changes, taking prescription medications, and having interventions or surgery (as recommended by your doctor).

sections.heading: Getting follow-up care from your doctor:
paragraphs: The frequency of your follow-up visits will be determined by your doctor. Diagnostic tests are necessary to determine what caused the cardiac event to prevent future episodes of sudden cardiac arrest. Testing may include electrocardiograms (ECGs or EKGs), ejection fraction, echocardiograms, cardiac catheterizations, and electrophysiology studies.

sections.heading: Ejection fraction (EF):
paragraphs: The ejection fraction refers to how much blood leaves the heart with every contraction. During an echocardiogram (echo) or other tests such as multi-gate acquisition (MUGA) scanning, cardiac catheterization, nuclear stress testing, and magnetic resonance imaging of the heart, the ejection fraction can be determined. Healthy hearts have an Ejection fraction between 55 and 65%. Because of your heart condition and the effectiveness of the therapies prescribed, your Ejection fraction can vary.

sections.heading: Reduce your risk factors:
paragraphs: You can reduce high blood pressure, cholesterol levels, manage your diabetes and weight if you have coronary artery disease (and even if you don’t), and thus reduce your risk of sudden cardiac arrest.

list: Stopping smoking
Maintaining a healthy weight
Regular exercise
Healthy low-fat diet
Managing sugar-level

blogs.title: Know More about Blood Pressure
blogs.medically_reviewed_by: Dr L Venkatesh, Director & Chief Consultant Physician – OMNI Hospitals, Visakhapatnam

paragraphs: Blood pressure is simply the physical pressure of blood in the blood vessels. Arteries carry blood from your heart to other parts of your body.

sections.subheading: What do the blood pressure numbers mean?
paragraphs: Blood pressure is measured using two numbers. The first number is called Systolic blood pressure, which measures the pressure in your arteries when your heart beats and the second number is called Diastolic blood pressure. It measures the pressure in your arteries when your heart rests between beats. When the measurement reads 120 systolic and 80 diastolic, it is said as “120/80 mmHg.”

Blood pressure varies from time to time, goes up and down with different normal daily activities. For example, exercise, changes in posture and even talking changes BP. Blood pressure remains higher during the day than at night and higher in the winter than in the summer. In adulthood, weight and BP are closely related. When weight goes up, BP tends to go up and we can lower BP by losing weight.

High BP is also known as hypertension. The BP changes throughout the day based on the person’s activity. The higher the BP levels, the more is the risk for other health problems, such as heart disease, heart attack and stroke. Most doctors consider BP of 140/90 and greater to be high. The exact values that doctors might interpret as high BP depends to an extent on individual circumstances. For patients with diabetes, hypertension is considered by some to pressure greater than 130/80.

sections.subheading: What are the signs and symptoms of high blood pressure?
list: Severe headache
Nosebleed
Fatigue
Blurred vision
Chest pain
Difficulty in breathing
Irregular heartbeat

paragraphs: The cause of high BP depends on a range of factors that could be because of genetic and environmental (lifestyle) factors that work together to raise bp. Some other factors are:
list: Smoking
Being overweight or obese
Lack of physical activity
Too much salt in the diet
Excess alcohol consumption
Stress
Adrenal and thyroid disorders
Sleep apnea

sections.subheading: What problems does high BP cause?
paragraphs: High BP damages your health in various ways, such as it can damage important organs like your heart, brain, kidneys, and eyes. But the good part is bp can be managed to lower your risk for serious health problems.

sections.subheading: How to prevent or manage high BP?
paragraphs: Many people with high BP can lower their bp into a healthy range or keep their numbers in a healthy range by making lifestyle changes. Talk with your health care team about
list: Getting at least 30 minutes of physical activity every day
Not smoking
Eating a healthy diet, limiting salt and alcohol
Keeping a healthy weight
Managing stress
