blogs.title: Everything You Need to Know About Heart Disease
blogs.medically_reviewed_by: Dr Y P Raju, Consultant Cardiologist, OMNI Hospitals - Kothapet

paragraphs: As you are all well aware, across the globe and exclusively in our Indian Subcontinent, cardiovascular disorders in the form of Heart attack (AMI) & Heart Failure(HF) are burgeoning by several folds of deaths in human kingdom is related to either Acute MI, that means out of 10 deaths, 6 deaths are related to cardiovascular disorders in the form of Acute Coronary Syndrome, Heart failure & Heart stroke. Unfortunately 1 out of every 3rd person suffering from Hypertension & Diabetics in our country. That’s why India became Diabetic & Cardiovascular diseases capital. There are two peaks of incidents of heart attacks in our country, the peak between 30-45 years (young) & another peak after 60 years (old).

sections.subheading: Principal reasons for Heart Stroke in young (30-45 years):
paragraphs: Sedentary lifestyle (Obesity & lack of physical activity)
Excessive consumption of high calories through foods & beverages. example: Pizzas, burgers & fried vegetarian & non vegetarian food and foods with high TFA( Trans Fatty acids).
list: Insulin Dependent Diabetes Mellitus
Excessive tobacco addiction
Genetic reasons
Environmental pollution
Undue mental stress and suffering
Night shift & stress-related jobs
Dyslipidemia
Hyperhomocysteinemia
Hyperuricemia

sections.subheading: Principal reasons behind Heart Attack (Acute MI) in middle-aged/elderly people (above 45 years):
list: Age factor
More chances in both men and women
Hypertension
Diabetes mellitus
In women after menopause
Dyslipidemia
Obesity & physical inactivity
Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD)

sections.subheading: Heart Attack (Acute Myocardial Infarction): Heart attacks are generally of 2 categories.

paragraphs: A heart attack does not always have obvious symptoms, such as pain in your chest, shortness of breath and cold sweats. In fact, a heart attack can actually happen without a person knowing it. It is called a silent heart attack or medically referred to as silent ischemia (lack of oxygen) to the heart muscle. This is generally seen in diabetic patients and heavy smokers, here even the ECG looks normal, But cardiac enzymes like Trop –T/ Trop-I/ CK MB are positive.

At times, patients under this category die before reaching the hospital. As patient himself misleads on his own, because he/she lacks significant and regular heart attack symptoms. Some people later recall their silent heart attack was mistaken for indigestion, nausea, muscle pain or a bad case of the flu.

Having a silent heart attack puts you at a greater risk of having another heart attack, which could be fatal. Having another heart attack also increases your risk of complications, such as heart failure.

In this category of Heart attack, patient will experience the general symptoms like chest pain, breathing difficulty (SOB), Palpitation, Diaphoresis (sweating), giddiness, vomiting etc,. Some patients may have abdominal burning discomfort & sometimes loose motions, and they converts into Heart attack. Sometimes the heart attack is often mistaken as gastric problem and food poison, because they will be symptoms causes to Heart attack. Sometimes patients with cough and mild shortness of breath are diagnosed having upper/ lower respiratory tract infections. Some patients may present with giddiness with transient loss of consciousness due to nonsustained ventricular tachy arrhythmias in Anterior wall MI may often mistaken as CVA / TIA( Brain Stroke).

Some patients may have throat pain and jaw discomfort due to predominantly radiating pain from chest & therefore often mislead as ENT problems. Therefore the dictum is – pain anywhere from head to abdominal area should be evaluated for cardiac disease.

If you wonder if you’ve had a silent heart attack or MANIFEST heart attack, talk to your doctor. A review of your symptoms, health history and a physical exam can help your doctor decide if more tests are necessary.

sections.subheading: How to Recognise Acute MI/Heart Attack

paragraphs: 1st Test - ECG (Electrocardiogram)

Unfortunately, reliable only in 60% of cases, but in 40% cases ECG looks normal & hence misplaced as normal.  But we must not treat this as normal case, we need to check with the second level of testing. Here If ECG is positive, then we call it as ST Elevation MI (STEMI).
2nd Test - 2D Echo

Even in 2D ECHO test we will not get complete accurate results for all the cases. Unfortunately, it is normal in 10% of the cases. If this is misleading as normal, please check with the Cardiac Biomarkers test.
3rd Test - Cardiac Biomarkers

Here check for the levels in testing Troponin T(TROP -T) or troponin I(TROP – I) or Creatine Kinase Muscle/Brain(CK-MB). If these levels are positive, then there is high suspension of the heart attack. If ECG looks normal and patient gets results in Cardiac Biomarkers test, then this heart attack is named as Non ST Elevation MI (NON STEMI). This means Heart Stroke with Normal EKG.
4th Test - Coronary Angiography (CAG)

Angiography is the final test for more specific investigation and confirmation. Angiogram gives us the information about the diagnosis as well as prognosis & guides to future management. As is gives further information about the severity of blocks, number of blocks, location of blocks, out come of patient & need for PTCA (angioplasty stenting) management or CABG (Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting) management or Medical management.

NOTE: TMT must be avoided in those patients with high suspension of Acute MI, despite the negative results in ECG, 2D ECHO & positive Cardiac Biomarkers. Conclusively Heart attack is life threatening, the only early suspension is key and institution of appropriate therapy. Either Thrombolytic therapy or PTCA(Percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty) is paramount to mitigate the mobility and mortality.

subpara:

blogs.title: Heart Failure

medically_reviewed_by.name: Dr T Pramod Rao
medically_reviewed_by.designation: MD, DNB (Medicine), DM (Cardiology), HOD & Sr Consultant - Department of Cardiology, OMNI Hospitals, Kukatpally

paragraphs: The function of the heart is to take deoxygenated blood in and pump out the oxygenated blood to the rest of the organs. In the case of heart failure, the heart fails to pump the amount of blood that it normally pumps. Certain conditions like hypertension or narrowed coronary arteries due to cholesterol deposition weaken the heart walls over a period due to which the blood is not pumped efficiently.
The conditions that cause heart failure are not all reversible. However, treatments are provided to improve the signs and symptoms of heart failure.
Heart failure is usually related to other condition or disease that may include the following:
list: Coronary artery diseases: This is a condition in which the coronary arteries are narrowed or get blocked
Congenital heart defect: A defect that is present from birth can affect walls of the heart
Heart attack: When a heart attack occurs, the blood supply to the heart is stopped which may lead to heart failure
Cardiomyopathy: This is a condition in which the heart muscles weaken due to reasons like infections, drug or alcohol abuse, genetic issues.
Other conditions: Other medical conditions like high blood pressure, diabetes, kidney disease, thyroid problems and heart valve disease may lead to heart failure.
subpara: Lifestyle changes like weight management, exercising and avoiding alcohol and drug abuse are vital, which needs to be avoided

paragraphs: Heart failure can be a chronic (ongoing) or acute (sudden) condition. The symptoms of heart failure include:
list: Shortness of breath on exertion followed by shortness of breath even at rest
Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea or PND, i.e. shortness of breath and coughing that usually occurs in the night
Easy fatigue and tiredness
Pedal oedema i.e., accumulation of fluid in the feet or lower legs that increases in the evening time
Intermittent chest pain
Increased frequency of urination at night
Stomach pain
Loss of appetite
Indigestion
Dry cough
Giddiness

paragraphs: A number of clinical symptoms and lab investigations help in the diagnosis of heart failure. The clinical signs of heart failure are:
list: Tachycardia: abnormal rapid heart rate
Pulse alternorme (alternate pulse is weak)
Pedal oedema
Cold periphery
Cardiomegaly: an enlarged heart that may lead to abnormal heart rhythms
S3
Constrictive defect
2D Echo: to investigate the left ventricle function, pulmonary arterial hypertension (high blood pressure of lungs) and inferior vena cava plethora (lack of collapsibility)

Blood tests: Haemoglobin (to check for anaemia), elevated B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) or N-terminal pro-b-type natriuretic (NT pro-BNP) to detect, diagnose or evaluate the severity of heart failure.
ECG (Electrocardiogram): To give an idea about conduction defect and changes due to a heart attack.

Chest X-ray: To view the condition of the heart and lungs. 2D echo provides details about the size of heart chambers, pumping function of the heart, any leakage of valves, lung pressure and presence of fluid. Other tests suggested are CT - Scan, MRI, Coronary angiogram, Myocardial biopsy and stress test.

paragraphs: After the diagnosis of heart failure, various non-pharmacological and pharmacological measures are suggested to the patient. A change in lifestyle is recommended to the patients diagnosed with heart failure. Weight management, exercises that do not cause physical strain, drug and alcohol abstinence, reduction in intake of salt and restrictions on fluid intake are suggested. Other methods of treatment include:
list: Medication: Medicines like diuretics help attain frequent urination, so that fluid is not retained in the body are suggested. Medications to improve the heart pumping function and reduction of load on the heart are prescribed by the cardiologists.

Surgery: Depending on your medical history and current status, surgeries are performed to improve the heart pumping function. Coronary bypass surgery and heart valve replacement or repairs are the types of surgery performed. With various trial and encouraging results, heart transplants are also a preferred method of treatment

Implantable devices: Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillators (ICDs) help in providing a direct shock treatment through pacemaker, whenever an abnormal rhythm is detected. Cardiac resynchronisation therapy (CRT - P/D) is used in which by programming a pacing device, the heart is stimulated mechanically to establish the synchronisation of heart-pumping functions.

blogs.title: A case report on Minimal Invasive Cardiac Bypass Surgery

paragraphs: Cardiac bypass surgery is one of the most invasive and major surgical procedures. Following an open cardiac bypass surgery, the time taken for wound healing and patient getting back to work ranges between 6-8 weeks. A minimal invasive approach to this major surgery has opened the doors for faster recovery and smaller wound without the need to cut open a bone.

One such surgery was performed in OMNI Hospitals, Kurnool this month. The patient, Harikrishna, 32 years, was diagnosed as a case of coronary artery disease not amenable to angioplasty, hence referred for bypass surgery. Since he is a young man with lean built, a decision was made to perform minimal invasive bypass surgery. A muscle splitting, rib preserving incision was made on the left side of the chest and chest cavity was entered. The left internal mammary artery on the chest wall was harvested and bypass surgery was performed on the beating heart without heart-lung machine support. The patient withstood the procedure well and was fit to move around on the first post-operative day itself. He was discharged within 5 days of procedure and can return to work within ten days of surgery.
subpara: Minimal invasive surgery is the new trend developing in the field of cardiac surgery where with help of special instruments, cardiac surgeries are performed through a small incision on the left or right side of chest without cutting any bone. Hence the blood loss is low, chances of wound infection are less, recovery is faster and patient can get back to work within two weeks. It also avoids the big and sometimes ugly scar in the middle of the chest. At OMNI Hospitals, Kurnool, we provide an option of minimal invasive cardiac surgery for suitable patients.

Dr Akshay Singh
Consultant Cardiothoracic Surgeon
OMNI Hospitals, Kurnool

blogs.title: Case Of Sudden Cardiac Arrest – The Golden Hour
blogs.author: OMNI Hospitals

paragraphs: A 49 year old female patient was brought to the ER on 23rd January 2020 at 11:00pm by her sons on a 2 wheeler in an unresponsive state. According to her attendant she complained of sudden onset difﬁculty in breathing/chest discomfort at home around 10:00pm after which she collapsed and was unresponsive. She was apparently doing well with no acute complaints until 10:00pm and the previous couple of days.

She is known to be diabetic and hypertensive since more than 10 years, with history of Coronary Artery Disease, post PTCA and stenting done 3 years back. She is on regular medication for all the above.

On receiving at ER the patient was found to be unconscious, cyanotic and not responding to even deep pain stimulus. GCS was E1V1M1. Her carotid was absent, BP could not be recorded and GRBS – 569mg/dl, peripheries cold and saturation could not be recorded.

In the absence of carotid pulse, CPR was promptly started, peripheral venous access obtained, patient was immediately intubated and after 5 cycles of high quality CPR according to ACLS protocols, ROSC was achieved and patient started on mechanical ventilation.

Post-CPR, ABG showed metabolic acidosis with ph. 7.147, Bicarbonate-11mmol/L, pO2-253, pCO2-33.7 mmHg, cLac-12.8. ECG after ROSC showed ST depressions in lateral leads with T inversions. CT brain (P) post-ROSC showed no sign of bleed or acute changes. X-Ray chest, showed haziness/patchy opacities in both lungs with p/o consolidation.
Patient was managed in the ER with ﬂuid boluses, bicarbonate correction and insulin infusion for high sugars. Empiric antibiotic coverage started, until blood reports were awaited.

She was provisionally diagnosed with recurrent CAD, cardiac arrest, post CPR status, ?DKA, ?HONC, ?LRTI and to rule out CVA. She was also on anti-platelet medication, clexane, neuroprotective medication and other supportive medication and was then shifted to MICU.
The patient responded slowly and regained consciousness within 8 hours. The patient was able to understand verbal commands and was responding to them properly.

Preliminary blood work showed, WBC – 15800, normal renal function except for RBS of >500mg/dl, Total bilirubin of 1.3 and slightly elevated SGPT and SGOT. Her serum procalcitonin at admission was 2.9. Her urine was negative for ketone bodies. Remaining blood investigations were fairly normal.

2D Echo showed dilated LV, with global hypokinesia of LV and severe LV dysfunction with EF of 25%, Grade II diastolic dysfunction, mild MR and mildly Plethoric IVC. Her TROPONIN – I was negative. She was slowly weaned off of insulin. Diuretics, Beta Blockers and Dobutamine infusion was started.

Pulmonology consultant advised for antibiotic upgradation and other supportive medication. Neurology consultation was unremarkable, with no focal deﬁcits, normal CT brain and extubation of the patient was planned accordingly.

Later she developed mild hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia and was corrected accordingly. WBC showed a decreasing trend. On 26th January 2020 patient was put on T-Piece ventilation, was monitored and then extubated in the afternoon of 26th January 2020.
The patient responded to the upgraded antibiotics and other symptomatic medication, evident in improving clinical status, reducing WBC counts and improved chest X-ray ﬁndings.
The patient underwent CAG in the afternoon of 27th January 2020 with the following ﬁndings:
CAD – DOUBLE VESSEL DISEASE (LCX & RCA) MID LAD STENT 40-50% INSTENT RESTENOSIS PATENT DISTAL RCA STENT
LCX was ruled to be the culprit vessel for the patient going into sudden cardiac arrest. Based on the above CAG ﬁndings the patient was suggested for PTCA+, STENTS TO MID LCX & MID RCA.
Due to ﬁnancial constraints the attendants did not want to undergo further management and the patient was discharged at request in a haemodynamically stable condition.

A day post extubation patient was able to speak well, could recognise her children, no focal deﬁcits were observed, memory was found to be excellent with the patient being able to completely recall the events preceding her presentation to ER. She could clearly remember her developing chest discomfort and also she being driven on a two wheeler between her two sons.

Hence it can be safe to presume that in this patient the time between cardiac arrest and the start of CPR is very narrow and one of the main contributing factors for the patient making a complete neurological recovery post cardiac arrest and ROSC following CPR.

Quick recognition of cardiac arrest, prompt and high quality CPR, good ICU monitoring with timely recognition and correction of metabolic parameters, coordination between various specialties/ specialists also play a vital role in a successful outcome.
A Note to the General Public
THE GOLDEN HOUR
The ﬁrst hour after the onset/start of heart attack is called the golden hour. Appropriate action within ﬁrst 60 minutes of a heart attack can reverse its effects.

The Golden Hour is a window of opportunity that impacts a patient’s survival and quality of life following a heart attack. It is a critical time. This is because the heart muscle starts to die within 80-90 minutes after it stops getting blood and within six hours, almost all the affected parts of the heart could be irreversibly damaged.
So, the faster normal blood ﬂow is re-established, the lesser would be the damage to the heart.

blogs.title: Cardiovascular Risk Factors

paragraphs: Cardiovascular diseases have become highly common in most of the people due to the lifestyle changes in the current era. People in this generation are more prone to cardiovascular diseases because of their improper habits, obesity, lack of exercises and more.

There are several reasons for the cause of cardiovascular diseases. Some of the heart-related diseases eventually lead to cardiovascular risk factors. Get to know more about the risk factors in heart diseases, coronary arteries and other cardiovascular diseases through this blog.

Here is an excerpt from a video interview with Dr. Shashanka Chunduri, Senior Consultant Interventional Cardiologist, Omni Hospitals, Vizag on Cardiovascular risk factors, types of risk factors, its causes, heart disease complications and the ways to prevent different types of cardiovascular diseases.
Cardiovascular diseases are conditions that usually affect the heart function and the structures of the heart. Cardiovascular diseases are classified into four major groups.
1. Heart Attacks:
These are the diseases that affect the heart. A heart attack is also known as myocardial infarction.
2. Brain Strokes:
A brain stroke is another group that comes under cardiovascular diseases. Due to the interruption or reduction of blood flow to the brain, people usually get a brain stroke.
3. Peripheral Artery Diseases:

In this group of cardiovascular disease, lower limbs of the patient are involved. Some feel extreme pain in the limbs while walking. Others may develop ulcers that require interventions. Some patients may even require amputations.
4. Aortic Diseases:
These involve the aorta, the largest artery in the human body that comes from the heart and supplies the entire body.
Aortic Aneurysm: It is the enlargement of the aorta.
Aortic Dissection: A serious condition where ruptures take place in the wall of the aorta.
These are the four major groups in cardiovascular diseases.

sections.subheading: Q. What are the main risk factors for cardiovascular diseases?
paragraphs: The risk factors for cardiovascular diseases are classified as modifiable and non-modifiable risk factors. Non-modifiable factors are not in our control, while modifiable ones can be handled by making lifestyle changes.

sections.subheading: Q. What are the Non-modifiable risk factors?
list: A. The non-modifiable risk factors are uncontrollable. Some of the major non-modifiable risk factors include:
Age: With age, vascular systems change—like calcium deposits and small vessel damage—making cardiovascular diseases more common after 70 years.
Gender: Males are more prone to heart diseases due to lifestyle and genetic reasons. Estrogen in females offers protection until menopause.
Family History: A family history of heart attack before 55 years increases risk.
Ethnicity: South Asians and Africans are at higher risk compared to Europeans.
Socio-economic status: Lower socio-economic groups face higher risks due to lifestyle and awareness issues.

sections.subheading: Q. Is high salt bad for the heart?
paragraphs: A. Yes. The increased usage of salt is definitely a risk to the cardiovascular system. It enhances the blood pressure and salt has fluid retention. People must restrict the usage of salt to 3 grams in their day to day basis. As a result, we can reduce the chances of getting high blood pressure.

Pickles, fast food items, papads and other things have added salt. Mostly, people across the world use more salt in their daily food. It is advisable to minimize the usage of salt and added salt to our routine foods. This way, one can reduce cardiovascular risks.

sections.subheading: Q. What are the modifiable risk factors?
paragraphs: A. Modifiable risk factors are controllable risk factors. Some of them include:

Smoking: People who smoke frequently are highly prone to heart attacks, strokes and other cardiovascular diseases. Nicotine, carbon monoxide, harmful tobacco products, carbon dioxide and more are present in the smoking products. Due to the usage of nicotine, it constrains the blood vessels eventually causing blood flow interruptions. There are increased chances of thrombus formation in the blood clots and blood vessels. If an individual stops smoking, it reduces the risks of cardiovascular diseases for about 30 to 36 percent.

Hypertension: It is also directly associated with various cardiovascular risks. Due to increased blood pressure, some of them may get brain strokes, heart attacks and renal failure. The ideal blood pressure in an individual is 120/80 or below 130.
Diabetes: It increases the chance of strokes. One must maintain normal blood sugar levels to prevent cardiovascular risk.
High Cholesterol: The higher deposits of cholesterol in blood vessels lead to heart blocks, heart attacks and more.

Obesity and Lack of Exercise: These two factors are highly prone to the cause of cardiovascular diseases.Unhealthy Diet: Increased consumption of saturated foods [from animal sources] is more prone to cardiovascular risks like heart attacks and strokes.

sections.subheading: Q. At what age should one worry about cholesterol?
paragraphs: A. Cholesterol is another major concern in several folks across the world. In fact, cholesterol gets deposited in the body. According to the US recommendations, one must get to know his/her lipid profile at the age of 20. Further, they can get cholesterol level check-up every 5 or 6 years. People who reach 40 years of age, they must assess the lipid profile as well as the cardiovascular risk score assessment.

One must maintain their cholesterol levels based on these assessments. If you already have a heart attack or stroke then, you must maintain lower LDL i.e., less than 70 LDL. If you don’t have any such heart problems but have smoking habits, hypertension and above 40 years then, you must get your risk assessment. After checking the score, if the risk is more than 20 percent then, you must definitely maintain the LDL less than 70. If the risk is below 7.5 then, you can have 100 LDL.

sections.subheading: Q. What are the common habits that damage the heart?
paragraphs: A. Some of the common habits that cause severe damage to the heart include smoking, drugs, and more. Due to these habits, people may get Vasoconstriction at a younger age.
list: Lack of Exercise
Obesity
Fast food and junk food with high salt or trans fats
Reusing oil more than twice

sections.subheading: Q. Can stress cause heart disease?
paragraphs: A. Any kind of stress at home or office may lead to sympathetic overactivity. It causes high blood pressure. As a result, it causes hormonal imbalance and also causes endothelial damage because of increased stress. All these are more prone to cardiac events. Some of the stress-relieving activities like doing meditation will definitely help in preventing heart attacks.

sections.subheading: Q. What is good cholesterol and bad cholesterol?
paragraphs: A. Cholesterol is the major lipid in the body. As they are not water-soluble and cannot flow in the blood, they are attached to proteins and form lipoproteins. Good cholesterol and Bad Cholesterol are the two types of lipoproteins.

Cholesterol is actually required for the growth of body cells or membranes in the blood. It also helps in the production of sex hormones. Usually, excess cholesterol forms in the body coming through diet, the liver will deposit in the blood vessels. It forms blocks in the blood vessels.

Good Cholesterol is also known as HDL [High-Density Lipoprotein] that works like a scavenger. It has the ability to collect excess cholesterol from the cells or blood vessels and carries it to the liver. In the liver, good cholesterol is metabolized. HDL removes cholesterol from blood vessels and carries it to the liver.On the other hand, LDL is Low-Density Lipoprotein or bad cholesterol. It carries cholesterol from the liver to tissues and other parts whenever required. If bad cholesterol is in excess quantity, it gets deposited in the blood vessels and leads to the formation of clots.

sections.subheading: Q. Is it possible to get a heart attack with no risk factors?
paragraphs: A. Yes, it is possible. Almost 70 percent of people may get a heart attack with some risk factors. The remaining 30 percent of them may get a heart attack without showing any sort of risk factors. Some of the genetic studies are being done to find out the actual cause of heart attack.

sections.subheading: Q. What Kind of Exercise Benefits the Heart? How much time?
paragraphs: A. Some of the exercises like aerobic exercise will benefit the heart by diminishing the endothelial dysfunction. An individual must do 30 minutes a day or 150 minutes per week may benefit the heart. Some of the aerobic exercises include running, jogging, swimming, treadmill and more.

sections.subheading: Q. Explain the primary and secondary heart disease preventions?
paragraphs: A. Primary prevention is taking necessary steps to prevent the occurrence of heart diseases like stroke or heart attack. In such a case, the person must take risk factor assessment and prevent it before the occurrence of cardiovascular disease.

On the other hand, secondary prevention is nothing but preventing the heart attack for the second time. It means, the person might have an attack earlier and should try to prevent the cardiovascular disease that may cause for the second time.

sections.subheading: Q. What is the Ideal Blood Pressure? What are the Signs of heart strokes?
paragraphs: A. The ideal blood pressure in an individual is less than 120/80. Above 120 to 139 is considered normal high blood pressure. If the blood pressure is above 130/80, it is considered stage 1 hypertension.

sections.subheading: Q. Are changing oils periodically good for the heart?
paragraphs: A. There are different types of fats such as saturated, unsaturated, monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fats. One must avoid the usage of saturated fats and Trans fats. Saturated fats are produced from animal sources such as ghee, curd and more. People should minimize the usage of saturated fats to at least 10 percent in the total calories.

On the other hand, Unsaturated, monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fats are beneficial to the heart. They are available in the form of vegetables, nuts, fish and more. By changing oils periodically or monthly basis, it will be definitely beneficial to the heart. It can be olive oil, rice bran oil, sunflower oil and others.

sections.subheading: Q. Is refined oil good for health?
paragraphs: A. There is no significant harm to the usage of refined oil. But, the case is one shouldn’t reuse the oil for the second time. Reusing the oil more than 2 or 3 times will be harmful to the heart.

sections.subheading: Q. Is it important to know your BMI?
paragraphs: A. Obesity is a risk factor in cardiovascular diseases. BMI is Body Mass Index. One should balance their height and weight by checking the BMI. If an individual’s weight is more than 25 kgs is considered overweight and above 30 kgs is obese. Ideal waist circumference in men is 90 cm while it is 80 cm in women.
A. Yes, it is possible to prevent cardiovascular disease by up to 75 percent by following certain steps.
list: By avoiding smoking
Eating a healthy diet
Being physically active
Normal blood pressure
Normal Blood Glucose Level
Having normal cholesterol and BMI

sections.subheading: Q. What is the role of Aspirin in the prevention of Heart Disease?
paragraphs: A. Aspirin plays a key role in the prevention of secondary cardiovascular diseases. But, one should use it only after when the doctor prescribes it. In terms of primary prevention, the usage of Aspirin is not recommended. If the person’s age is above 50 years and having a risk of about 10 percent then, the doctors may advise them to take 75mg of Aspirin. Before taking this medicine, the patient must assess their risks like bleeding.

sections.subheading: Q. How common are heart complications from non-cardiac surgery?
paragraphs: A. The risk is less than 5 percent in non-cardiac surgery patients. The heart complications may be high in peripheral vascular surgeries, aortic surgeries, cancer surgeries and major abdominal bisections. In some patients, they may get pulmonary thromboembolism.

subpara:

blogs.title: How To Keep Your Heart Healthy

medically_reviewed_by.name: Dr Pramod Kumar Rao
medically_reviewed_by.designation: Sr. Consultant - Dept. of Cardiology, OMNI Hospital, Kukatpally

paragraphs: A healthy heart is central to overall good health. Embracing a healthy lifestyle at any age can prevent heart disease and lower your risk for a heart attack or stroke. You are never too old or too young to begin taking care of your heart.

True, the younger you begin making healthy choices, the longer you can reap the benefits. But swapping good habits for bad to promote good health can make a difference, even if you’ve already suffered a heart attack.

Here is an excerpt from a video interview of Dr Pramod Rao, DM(Cardiology), Sr. Consultant and Interventional Cardiologist at Omni Hospitals, Kukatpally, Hyderabad on various heart problems measures that can be taken to keep it at bay.

sections.subheading: Q. What are the general heart problems and diseases that we face?
paragraphs: A. The most common heart problem is chest pain. There are many causes for chest pain including cardiac arrests. The symptoms for the cause of chest pain are carefully analysed and then the cause can be detected. Heart failure associated with swelling of the feet and excessive sweating is also a common heart problem.

sections.subheading: Q. What are the treatment options for heart failures?
paragraphs: A. People suffering from heart attacks and heart failures are immediately taken to the ICU for an ECG. Depending on the ECG scan, the attack or failure is treated. If a patient is brought to the hospital during the ‘golden hour’, then with immediate scans and stenting, the person can evade the side-effects of it.

sections.subheading: Q. When should a person visit the doctor if he/she suffers from any kind of heart problem?
paragraphs: A. Nowadays due to the change in lifestyle, acidity and acid reflux problems have become very common and hence people suffering from heartburn too. But when the pain doesn’t subside after taking antacids, then a person should immediately rush to the hospital for treatment.
Hence, any type of chest discomfort shouldn’t be neglected and should be brought to the notice of a doctor immediately.

sections.subheading: Q. How can we prevent heart diseases?
paragraphs: A. The prevention of heart disease starts from a change in the lifestyle. Due to an inactive lifestyle, many people from a younger age itself face issues like obesity, diabetes, thyroid issues and more.
The following precautions can be taken to prevent heart diseases:
list: 1. Regular exercise
2. Healthy and balanced diet
3. Involvement in a sports activity
4. No smoking
5. Limited alcohol consumption

sections.subheading: Q. What kind of a diet should be followed by a person to prevent heart problems?
paragraphs: A. Diet is a major factor that contributes to lifestyle changes. After a person suffers from any kind of heart problem, a low-salt diet should be taken to keep the blood pressure levels balanced.
A diet rich in proteins, fibres, minerals and nutrients will help prevent heart problems. Hence, incorporating a lot of fruits, vegetables and nuts in one’s diet helps to prevent heart problems.

sections.subheading: Q. What activities does a person suffering from heart problems have to avoid?
paragraphs: AA. s the blood pumping capacity of the heart of a person suffering from heart problems is less and incompetent, heavy exercising or sports activities should be avoided. Activities like brisk walking or normal paced walking can still be a part of the lifestyle.
A. No two 2D Echocardiograms will be the same as every cardiogram completely depends on the lab assistant or cardiologist, equipment in the laboratory, the day and time when the cardiogram is done.

sections.subheading: Q. Is alcohol good for the heart?
paragraphs: A. For ages, it has been accepted that a peg or two of alcohol per day is good for the body. But for people suffering from heart problems of cholesterol issues, alcohol is not good and is not prescribed.

sections.subheading: Q. Is river fish good for the heart?
paragraphs: A. Any type of fish contains omega 3 fatty acids so it is good for the body. Hence, river or sea fish, both are good for the body.

sections.subheading: Q. How can a person increase his/her good cholesterol?
paragraphs: A. There are two types of cholesterol, HDL and LDL. HDL is the good cholesterol whereas LDL is the bad cholesterol. The only way to increase HDL and keep it balanced is by regular exercise.
A. Yes, to some extent high cholesterol is hereditary in nature.

sections.subheading: Q. How often should cholesterol be checked?
paragraphs: A. If a person is suffering from abnormal cholesterol levels and is under medication, then a cholesterol check-up every 3–6 months is necessary. If a person has balanced cholesterol levels, then a check-up every one year is more than enough.

sections.subheading: Q. Are the chances of a heart attack greater in a person who has high blood pressure?
paragraphs: A. Yes, the chances of a heart attack are greater in a person with high blood pressure. Regular exercise, timely medication, balanced diet and mental peace will help a person keep away from various heart problems as much as possible.

sections.subheading: Q. How does being overweight affect a person’s blood pressure? What kind of diet should be taken to lose weight?
paragraphs: Being overweight causes abnormality in the body functions like hormonal issues, decreased metabolism rate, insulin level fluctuation and more. This, in turn, affects basic body functions like blood pressure.
Diet is a major factor that contributes to lifestyle changes. A diet rich in proteins, fibres, minerals and nutrients will help control body weight and will also keep a person fit.
Hence, incorporating a lot of fruits, vegetables and nuts in one’s diet is very important. To lose weight, junk food, fatty foods and fried food should be avoided.

sections.subheading: Q. What is the difference between the first heart attack and second heart attack? Why do people sometimes die during their first heart attack?
paragraphs: A. A person can die during any heart attack. It depends on the intensity of the attack. If the left side artery is majorly blocked and diseased during a heart attack, the person will die immediately. If the right side arteries are blocked or diseased during the attack, as there are two arteries on the right side and hence there is a chance of survival.
The chances of survival of a person during a heart attack depend on the myocardium levels and not on the number of heart attacks that the person has suffered from.

sections.subheading: Q. How much sodium should be incorporated in one’s diet?
paragraphs: A. Depending on the person’s medical history and problems, sodium levels should be incorporated. If a person is suffering from any kind of medical conditions, especially kidney-related issues, then less salt should be taken as excess salt tends to remain in the person’s body itself.
If a person is normal and isn’t suffering from any medical issues, normal levels of salt can be ingested as any excess salt will be passed out in the form of urine or sweat.

sections.subheading: Q. What can be the effect of stress on the heart?
paragraphs: A. When a person is under stress, excess hormones are secreted. These hormones that are secreted in excess are called ‘sympathetic hormones.’ This increases the heart rate. As the heart is now pumping blood at a faster rate, all the body functions are affected. Regular exercise and yoga will help reduce stress levels.

sections.subheading: Q. How often are heart check-ups required for a person?
paragraphs: A. Once a person reaches 30 years of age, even if they are healthy and all body functions are normal, a total health check-up is necessary to rule out any underlying medical condition. This helps in early diagnosis and hence early treatment.

sections.subheading: Q. How to identify an initial heart attack?
paragraphs: A. Any uneasy sensation or discomfort in the chest that lasts for more than 3–5 mins can be taken as a symptom for a heart issue and should not be neglected. Rush to the nearest hospital and get an ECG done to rule out the causes for uneasiness and discomfort.

sections.subheading: Q. Can a vegan lifestyle reduce one’s chance of contracting heart problems?
paragraphs: A. Yes, a vegan and healthy lifestyle will definitely reduce one’s chance of contracting heart problems.

sections.subheading: Q. What are the habits to practise for a healthy heart?
paragraphs: A. The following habits should be practised for a healthy heart:
list: • Eat healthily.
• Get active.
• Stay at a healthy weight.
• Quit smoking and stay away from secondhand smoke.
• Control your cholesterol and blood pressure.
• Drink alcohol only in moderation.
• Manage stress.

subpara:
Dr Pramod Kumar Rao
Sr. consultant – Dept. of Cardiology
OMNI Hospital, Kukatpally

blogs.title: The Management of Chronic Illness During Summer Heat
blogs.medically_reviewed_by: Dr. Srinivasulu Talacheru, General Physician, Diabetologist, and Critical Care Specialist

paragraphs: Summer is typically viewed as the season of rest, relaxation, and enjoyment of the great outdoors. However, those with chronic conditions may find that rising temperatures present specific challenges. Managing chronic illness during the heat of the summer takes some extra care and attention. Heat and illness can be a tricky balance—hot weather can trigger flare-ups and increase risks of dehydration. That being said, it is possible to have fun in the summer heat while living with chronic illness if you manage your health with these tips and strategies.

sections.heading: Understanding the Risks: Heat and Illness
paragraphs: While summer time can be synonymous with rest, relaxation, and enjoyment of the great outdoors, many individuals living with chronic illness see summer time not without its own share of challenges – especially if the hot weather of summer is viewed as a risk factor against their health. When we address chronic illness in hot weather it can take a little mindfulness & contemplation. We need to consider the risks and ensure we draw the fine line not only with temperature and illness but also with hydrotherapy and other potential risk factors, given heat and ill health often lead to flare-ups and dehydration. So, yes, it is possible! Individuals living with the effects of chronic illness can live and enjoy the heat of summertime positively if they can be aware of their health and take into consideration the tips and strategies discussed here.

sections.heading: Top Summer Health Tips for Managing Chronic Illness
paragraphs: Here are a few simple yet effective tips to manage chronic conditions and stay safe in the summer heat:

There is a higher risk for dehydration in hotter surroundings, especially for those with chronic conditions. Build up hydration slowly each day. Focus on drinking before you feel thirsty. Avoid sugary or caffeinated beverages as they can cause dehydration.

subsections.subheading: • Limit Outdoor Activity During Peak Heat
paragraphs: Temperatures rise most from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Try to avoid activity during these hours. If you must be outside, wear breathable clothing and a wide-brimmed hat. Take breaks, stay in the shade, and hydrate often.

subsections.subheading: • Monitor Your Symptoms and Stay Cool
paragraphs: Watch for symptoms like restlessness, nausea, or heavy sweating. Use a cold washcloth on your neck or take a quick dip in cool water to regulate your body temperature.
Some medications may worsen sensitivity to heat. Speak to your doctor about adjusting medications if needed during summer, especially those related to heart disease, depression, or anxiety.
Use sunscreen with SPF 30 or higher and reapply every two hours. Wear sunglasses and a wide-brimmed hat to protect your face and eyes from the sun’s rays.
Keep indoor temperatures down using fans, air conditioning, or cold showers. A cooler bedroom improves sleep quality, which is vital for managing chronic illness.

sections.heading: Know the Warning Signs: Chronic Flare-ups in the Heat
paragraphs: Summer heat also triggers repeated cases of asthma, arthritis, and cardiovascular disease. Monitor your symptoms that change. For example, asthmatic patients will experience enhanced respiratory trouble amid heat, while arthritis patients will experience intensified pain and swelling in hot weather with humidity. Follow your instincts and respond if your body signals something different.

sections.heading: Special Considerations for Dehydration Risks
paragraphs: Dehydration is most dangerous in the condition of chronic disease patients as it has a sequence effect of complications. Summer dehydration leads to kidney failure, hypotension, and electrolyte disturbance. To avoid dehydration:
list: Drink water throughout the day—even if you aren’t thirsty.
Avoid alcohol and caffeine, as they can cause further fluid loss.
Eat water-rich foods like cucumbers, watermelon, and strawberries.

paragraphs: While summer sun can be tough on individuals caring for chronic diseases, that does not imply staying indoors throughout the season. Through proper hydration, avoiding direct contact with hot conditions, checking in on your symptoms, and increased precautions, a healthy and active summer can still be had. Always remain connected with your health care provider for individualized advice and changes in your care regimen.

Keep in mind that the secret to surviving chronic illness over the summer is to be proactive. With some preparation and awareness, you can enjoy the sunshine without compromising your safety and health.
This blog has been medically reviewed by Dr. Srinivasulu Talacheru, General Physician, Diabetologist, and Critical Care Specialist

blogs.title: Managing Diabetes to Reverse and Prevent Heart Disease: Essential Tips for Protecting Your Heart
blogs.author: OMNI Hospitals

sections.heading: Managing Diabetes and Heart Health
paragraphs: Diabetes is a chronic condition that affects millions globally, with its impact extending far beyond blood sugar control. One of the most significant risks associated with diabetes is the increased likelihood of heart disease. People with diabetes are at a higher risk of developing cardiovascular problems, such as heart attacks and strokes. The good news is that with proper management and proactive care, you can reverse and prevent heart disease while effectively managing diabetes.

sections.subheading: Here are some essential tips for managing diabetes to help protect your heart and enhance your overall health:
paragraphs: 1. Maintain Stable Blood Sugar Levels

Keeping blood sugar levels within a healthy range is crucial for diabetes management. Fluctuating levels can damage blood vessels and nerves, increasing the risk of heart disease. Regular blood sugar monitoring helps you track how foods, activities, and medications affect your glucose levels.

Work closely with your healthcare provider to establish a target blood sugar range and adjust your treatment plan as needed. Consistently maintaining stable levels will reduce complications such as kidney damage and nerve problems, safeguarding your heart in the process.
2. Follow a Heart-Healthy Diet

A balanced, heart-healthy diet is vital for managing diabetes and protecting your heart. Making the right food choices not only helps regulate blood sugar but also reduces the risk of cardiovascular complications. Focus on foods that prevent heart disease and provide essential nutrients.
Incorporate the following into your diet:
list: Fruits and vegetables: High in fiber, vitamins, and minerals, these help regulate blood sugar levels.
Whole grains: Options like brown rice, quinoa, and oats provide fiber to support blood sugar control and heart health.
Lean proteins: Choose chicken, fish, beans, or tofu over red meat to lower saturated fat intake.
Healthy fats: Include sources like olive oil, nuts, and avocados to improve cholesterol levels and reduce inflammation.

paragraphs: Avoid processed foods, refined sugars, trans fats, and excessive saturated fats, as these can lead to blood sugar spikes and increase cholesterol levels. Meal planning and portion control can further enhance your dietary efforts.
3. Exercise for Heart Health

Regular physical activity is a cornerstone of diabetes management and heart disease prevention. Exercise improves insulin sensitivity, helping to stabilize blood sugar levels, while strengthening your heart and lowering blood pressure.

Aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise weekly. Activities like brisk walking, cycling, swimming, and strength training are excellent options for enhancing heart health. Begin slowly if you’re new to exercising and consult your healthcare provider before starting a new routine.
4. Check Cholesterol Levels and Blood Pressure Regularly

High cholesterol and elevated blood pressure are significant risk factors for heart disease, especially for individuals with diabetes. Monitoring these metrics is essential to prevent heart disease and maintain overall health.
To manage these levels effectively:
list: Follow a heart-healthy diet rich in whole, plant-based foods.
Stay physically active to improve cholesterol and reduce blood pressure.
Take prescribed medications as directed to control cholesterol or hypertension.

paragraphs: Regularly checking your cholesterol and blood pressure levels helps identify issues early and minimizes complications.
5. Quit Smoking and Quit Alcohol Consumption

Smoking damages blood vessels and increases the risk of heart disease, making it particularly harmful for people with diabetes. Quitting smoking is one of the most effective ways to protect your heart.

Similarly, excessive alcohol consumption can lead to elevated blood pressure and weight gain, complicating diabetes management. If you drink, do so in moderation—no more than one drink per day for women and two for men.
6. Practice Meditation for Heart Health

Chronic stress can negatively affect blood sugar levels and heart health. Incorporating meditation for heart health, such as mindfulness meditation, yoga, or breathing exercises, can reduce stress and improve your overall well-being.
Other stress-reducing activities include walking in nature, pursuing hobbies, and practicing gratitude. These techniques help regulate cortisol levels, reducing their harmful effects on the heart.
7. Stay Consistent with Medications

Medications play a critical role in managing blood sugar, cholesterol, and blood pressure. Adhering to your prescribed medication regimen is essential for preventing complications and protecting your heart. If you experience side effects or difficulties with medications, consult your healthcare provider for adjustments.

sections.heading: Conclusion
paragraphs: Managing diabetes to reverse and prevent heart disease requires consistent effort and proactive lifestyle changes. By maintaining stable blood sugar levels, embracing a heart-healthy diet, engaging in regular exercise for heart health, and adopting stress-reducing practices like meditation for heart health, you can protect your heart and live a healthier life.
This article has been medically reviewed by Dr Nagavender Rao M, General Physician

blogs.title: Heat Stroke Precautions: Tips to Avoid Dehydration in Summer
blogs.medically_reviewed_by: Dr. Nagavender Rao M, MBBS, MD (General Medicine)

paragraphs: With rising temperatures soaring higher than 40°C in some places around India, it becomes imperative for everyone to stay cool, alert and hydrated this summer to avoid heat-related illnesses, such as dehydration, heat exhaustion, and heat stroke/summer stroke. Several heat wave warnings sweeping across the country have arisen, cautioning people to keep themselves safe during the summer season. Here, we have compiled a list of tips to keep yourself safe and hydrated this summer, but first, you should know about the symptoms of a heat stroke.

sections.subheading: What Happens if You Get a Heat Stroke?
paragraphs: Heat stroke and exhaustion occur when the body cannot control core body temperature. This happens as a result of excessive sun and heat exposure. You may experience signs of heat stroke, such as:
list: Dizziness
Fatigue
Headaches
Excessive sweating
Nausea and vomiting
High body temperature, often above 104 degrees

paragraphs: In severe cases, heat stroke can cause life-threatening symptoms. You may develop confusion, irrational thoughts, or seizures, which occur because the various body systems are shutting down. These are severe signs of heat stroke in adults and require immediate medical attention. If these symptoms arise, it's crucial to seek emergency medical care as early as possible. Heat stroke is a medical emergency that requires immediate treatment to prevent serious complications or death.

sections.subheading: Tips to Keep Yourself Safe from a Heat Stroke
paragraphs: Here are eight tips to keep yourself cool and safe from heat exhaustion this summer.
list:
Stay hydrated:
Staying hydrated is key to maintaining a healthy body temperature, particularly when exercising or going outdoors. When you're dehydrated, your body can't cool itself as effectively, which can cause heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Drinking adequate fluids throughout the day can help to prevent this. Keep a drink handy containing electrolytes, salt, and small amounts of sugar. Drink before you feel thirsty.

Wear loose-fitting, lightweight clothes:
Wear clothes that enable air to pass through, especially those made of cotton. Tight-fitting clothes that sit tight on your body will not allow your body to cool down properly.

Use sun protection:
Use proper protection like umbrellas, wide-brimmed hats, gloves, and SPF 30+ sunscreen. Reapply sunscreen every 2 to 3 hours or more often if swimming or sweating.

Get used to the heat:
Your body needs time to adjust to the heat, a process known as acclimatization. Gradually introduce yourself to outdoor heat exposure.

Don't overexert yourself:
Avoid intense workouts during peak heat hours. If unavoidable, stay well-hydrated and rest frequently.

Be aware of medicinal reactions:
Some medications can interfere with your body's ability to regulate temperature. Consult your doctor if you are on medications like diuretics or antihistamines.

Take it easy during the hottest parts of the day:
Schedule outdoor work in early morning or evening hours. Stay informed with hourly weather updates.

Pay special attention to at-risk people:
Children, infants, older adults, and people with chronic illnesses like obesity or COPD are more vulnerable. Keep their environments cool and ensure they stay hydrated. Never leave anyone in parked cars.

paragraphs: Heat stroke is not to be taken lightly. It is a serious condition that requires immediate medical care. If not treated promptly, it can lead to severe complications in the brain, heart, lungs, muscles, and kidneys. The damage worsens when heat stroke treatment is delayed. This underscores the urgency and importance of seeking medical help at the earliest signs of heat stroke.
This blog has been verified by Dr. Nagavender Rao M, MBBS, MD (General Medicine).

blogs.title: Neurology: Latest Findings in Brain Health

sections.heading: Brain Health Overview
paragraphs: The human brain is an intricate structure that constitutes billions of neurons, which still stuns scientists with its flexibility and sophistication. The neurological development of recent years has changed the field markedly, making the discovery of cognitive and brain health functions possible. From advances in comprehending neuroplasticity to revealing the processes behind neurological diseases, the latest trends in neuroscience offer exciting discoveries that may help develop treatments to treat brain health.

Neurology is an extensive field of medical research that focuses on diagnosing and treating diseases affecting the neurological system. Neurology explores the basic processes underlying brain function, from the complicated interactions between neurotransmitters to the intricate architecture of neurons. Equipped with specialised knowledge and diagnostic instruments, neurologists endeavour to mitigate pain and reinstate quality of life by navigating the complex terrain of neurological diseases.

sections.heading: Brain Health: Latest Findings
paragraphs: In the ever-evolving landscape of neuroscience, the year 2024 heralds a wave of innovation that has the potential to transform mental health completely. The future is full of exciting possibilities, ranging from the incorporation of generative AI in medical applications to the advancement of brain-computer interface technologies. Let's explore the most recent discoveries and developments influencing the area of neurology and brain care.

A symbiotic link between artificial intelligence and medicine has been created, opening up new paths for diagnosis and treatment. Generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) is transforming the field of neurology by providing new insights into the complex patterns of brain function. By examining large amounts of data, artificial intelligence algorithms are able to identify minute details that are invisible to the human eye. It further helps to speed up the diagnosis of neurological conditions and inform individualized treatment plans. AI is being used in hundreds of CT scans each day to highlight "muscle vs fat tissue" and to segment cancers in MRIs of the breast or lung. By automating these procedures, doctors can focus more of their attention on patient care. Through the utilisation of machine learning, healthcare professionals may anticipate treatment results more precisely, improving patient outcomes and rehabilitation timelines.

Brain-Computer Interfaces, or BCIs, allow a person's brain and an electrical device to communicate with each other. BCIs can be non-invasive, somewhat invasive, or fully implanted; they can gather and analyse brain impulses and convert them into orders. This either causes the brain to respond in kind or enables mental interaction between people and their surroundings. BCI technology overcomes the constraints imposed by neurological illnesses, promoting independence and autonomy. It may be used to operate prosthetic limbs with thought instructions or to restore voice and mobility in people who are paralysed. By 2024, neurology is anticipated to be the medical device speciality with the fastest pace of growth. BCIs are already being used by many individuals in their daily lives for simple control and communication.

Positron Emission Tomography (PET) radiotracers have revolutionised molecular imaging in neurology due to their exceptional sensitivity and specificity. Novel PET radiotracers give unparalleled insights into the development and course of neurological conditions by focusing on different biochemical pathways. PET imaging reveals the molecular foundations of brain diseases, opening the door for focused treatment approaches. Examples of these include deciphering the neuroinflammatory cascade in Alzheimer's disease and mapping dopaminergic failure in Parkinson's disease. Additionally, the development of theranostic radiotracers presents a promising avenue for customised treatment by facilitating the delivery of therapeutic payloads to diseased tissues in tandem with diagnostics. As a cornerstone of precision medicine, PET imaging transforms the field of neurological treatment with each radiotracer specifically designed to address the distinct pathophysiology of individual neurological disorders.

A major change in the field of diagnostic neurology is signalled by the advancement of Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) technology. Above and beyond simple anatomical imaging, sophisticated MRI methods reveal the brain's functioning architecture and the minute abnormalities indicative of neurological diseases. When combined with advanced analytical techniques, high-resolution imaging provides unmatched insights into the dynamics of brain networks, enabling early diagnosis and intervention. Furthermore, the use of artificial intelligence enhances the ability of MRI equipment to diagnose by expediting picture interpretation and improving diagnostic precision. With the ongoing development of MRI technology, its use in neurology is going beyond simple diagnosis to include proactive monitoring of brain health and individualised treatment planning. This is leading to improvements in the area of neuroimaging and improving care for patients.

With a range of psychiatric problems, psychedelic substances have gained attention for their potential medicinal properties. Because they alter how different brain regions interact with one another, psychedelics have been demonstrated to be effective in treating neurological and mental health conditions. These treatments are frequently used in combination with conventional "talk" therapy.

Psilocybin and MDMA, the two primary psychedelic chemicals, are hoped to be closer to becoming legally approved and more readily available in the near future. The power of psychedelics to provide transformational experiences and encourage neuronal plasticity has been the main focus of research into their potential for treatment. This research has provided new insights into the underlying processes of addiction, mood disorders, and trauma-related diseases. Promising outcomes have been shown in clinical trials investigating the use of psychedelics in combination with psychotherapy to reduce symptoms of anxiety, depression, and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). The advantages of these treatments have been seen long after the psychedelic experience.

sections.heading: Conclusion
paragraphs: The most recent discoveries on brain health highlight the astounding advancements and potential of neuroscience in tackling the intricacies of the human brain. The field of neurology is undergoing unparalleled advancements that have the potential to revolutionise the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of neurological disorders. Examples of these advancements include the integration of generative AI in clinical practice, the evolution of MRI machines, and the resurgence of psychedelics in neurological research. The future of brain health seems more promising than ever as we continue to solve the questions surrounding the brain and make use of cutting-edge technologies and treatment approaches.

blogs.title: Say Goodbye to Varicose Veins with Our Effective Treatment Procedure

paragraphs: Varicose veins can be more than simply a cosmetic concern; if not addressed, they can bring discomfort and health problems. They may lead to discomfort, pain, and insecurity for people who have them. Although some people may seek Varicose vein treatment for cosmetic purposes, it’s important to realize that ignoring varicose veins can have major negative health effects. Fortunately, there are extensive treatment choices that can help reduce symptoms and avoid consequences. Without any further delay, let’s understand this condition in detail.

sections.heading: What are Varicose Veins?
paragraphs: A medical problem known as varicose veins or Spider veins is characterised by swollen, bulging veins that stick out from the skin and are usually blue or purple in colour. Standing and walking put strain on the veins, which is why they usually appear in the legs and feet. Veins in your legs that are not strong enough and would not be able to do their job of returning the blood to your heart are the main reason for the appearance of varicose veins. So, the blood may gather in the veins, leading to dilatation and twisting of the affected veins. The likelihood of developing varicose veins can be increased by several factors, such as age, pregnancy, heredity, being obese, and inactivity. Even though they simply may not have any of the symptoms, while they are not treated, they may proceed to pain, discomfort and further health problems.

sections.subheading: The Risks Varicose Veins Pose to Health
paragraphs: Untreated varicose veins present serious health hazards that go beyond cosmetic concerns. These twisted, swollen veins can cause a number of problems if left untreated. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT), a disorder where blood clots develop inside the afflicted veins, is one of the most serious risks. Pulmonary embolism is a potentially fatal medical condition that may occur when a blood clot breaks free and enters the lungs.

Furthermore, if varicose veins are left untreated, they may develop into chronic venous insufficiency, a medical condition in which the veins are unable to efficiently return blood to the heart, resulting in skin changes, swelling, and even excruciating ulcers. Furthermore, there is a higher chance of irritation and skin infections when varicose veins are present for an extended period. In order to reduce these health risks and maintain the best possible vascular health, varicose veins must be treated as soon as possible.

Varicose veins are easily recognised by their appearance, characterised by swelling and enlargement. With time, they may twist and change colour to a dark purple or blue hue. Still, a number of other symptoms may also be present with the medical condition. The following are common indications and symptoms of varicose veins:
list: Particularly after prolonged standing, your legs may feel heavy and achy. The cause of this is the elevated vein pressure and inadequate circulation.
Swollen ankles and feet can occur from a buildup of fluid caused by varicose veins getting worse.
Itching around one or more veins might occur for certain people. Due to the varicose veins, this may occasionally also be a sign of a skin infection or skin ulcers.
You could observe colour changes in the skin on your legs and around your ankles over time. An increase in venous pressure can cause the skin to thicken, harden, or get darker.
Your leg veins enlarge, swell, and twist to the point that they are visible beneath the skin.

Restless legs syndrome, a disorder marked by an unpleasant sensation that makes you desire to move your legs, especially at night or after prolonged sitting, is another symptom that some individuals with varicose veins encounter.

paragraphs: Self-care techniques, compression stockings, and surgeries or procedures are possible treatments for varicose veins. Self-care practices may prevent the worsening of the veins. Exercise, elevating your legs when sitting or lying down, and using compression stockings are some ways to help reduce the discomfort associated with varicose veins. Any type of exercise, including yoga, aerobics, cycling, and walking, can push blood that has accumulated in your veins and enhance blood circulation in the legs. Your varicose veins specialists.can occasionally recommend medication to assist in treating the varicose vein symptoms. These may consist of painkillers to ease discomfort, diuretics to lessen swelling, or anticoagulants to stop blood clots.
To effectively manage varicose veins, there are fortunately a number of non-surgical therapy methods available:
list: Sclerotherapy: One common non-surgical treatment for varicose veins is sclerotherapy. In order to induce irritation and inflammation, a solution is injected straight into the vein that is afflicted. After the vein closes due to this inflammation, the treated vein eventually becomes absorbed by the body. Most patients recover quickly from therapy and are able to return to their regular activities right away.

Endovenous Laser Ablation (EVLA): Endovenous laser ablation, or EVLA for short, is a minimally invasive treatment in which the injured vein is gently heated and sealed using laser radiation. A tiny laser fibre goes into the afflicted vein during the treatment, and laser energy is administered, causing the vein to collapse and seal shut. The blood flow is then instinctively redirected by the body to healthier veins.

Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA): Radio waves are used in radiofrequency ablation, or RFA, a minimally invasive technique, to burn and destroy the damaged vein. A tiny catheter is introduced into the vein during the treatment, and radiofrequency radiation is then administered to cause the vein to shut. The body reroutes blood flow to healthier veins in a manner similar to EVLA.
Compression Treatment: You can wear compression stockings during the day. The stockings compress the legs, facilitating blood flow via the veins and leg muscles.

paragraphs: Surgery for varicose veins may be advised in severe situations. Usually, varicose vein removal is the procedure used to remove the problematic veins, forcing the blood to flow via healthy veins instead. Although this procedure works well, it can be invasive and take longer to heal. Techniques used in surgery include:
list: Ligation & Stripping: Surgeons perform ligation and stripping, which is the process of cutting and tying off a vein. When a vein is stripped, a tiny incision is made, and a thin tool is inserted into the vein. A further incision is made to extract the vein.
Phlebectomy: The surgeon performs a phlebectomy, making tiny incisions before using a special hook to remove the veins.

sections.subheading: How much time does it take to recover from a Vein Treatment?
paragraphs: The length of recovery varies according to the kind of therapy as well as individual conditions. After laser treatment for varicose veins like sclerotherapy, patients may usually anticipate very little recovery time—the majority are able to return to their regular activities the same day. But more invasive procedures like RFA or EVLA could necessitate a few days of bed rest and little exercise. To guarantee a seamless recuperation procedure, your healthcare practitioner will give you comprehensive post-treatment advice.

Untreated varicose veins can pose major health hazards and are more than simply a cosmetic problem. Thankfully, there are now minimally invasive and successful vein therapy options available to replace conventional surgery. With the ability to address underlying problems and promote lifestyle changes, comprehensive Varicose vein treatment strategies that incorporate various modalities may lead to even more impressive results.

It is imperative that you see experienced vascular surgeons or varicose veins specialists if you are exhibiting signs of varicose veins. In order to stop more problems, they can assess your condition, suggest a course of action for treatment, and offer advice on how to modify your lifestyle.

blogs.title: World Health Day 2024: Healthy Lifestyle & Awareness
blogs.medically_reviewed_by: Public Health Experts at Omni Hospitals

paragraphs: In the global effort to promote better lives and increase awareness around significant health concerns, World Health Day 2024 will mark yet another momentous milestone. This day, which falls on April 7th every year, is a powerful reminder of putting our health and well-being first in all aspects of life. World Health Day emphasises the necessity of group effort, spreading awareness around health, and dedication to adopting good habits and healthy lifestyles as the world continues to struggle with several health issues.
The theme for World Health Day 2024 is "My Health, My Right."

World Health Day 2024 focuses on everyone's fundamental right to access quality healthcare, regardless of location. The goal is to promote equitable health outcomes and ensure that all individuals have the opportunity to live healthy lives. In 2021, the World Health Organization (WHO) reported that over half of the global population lacked access to essential healthcare services. This theme aims to raise awareness about this inequality and encourage efforts to address it.
list: High-quality healthcare: Accessing healthcare is more than just making it available. The need for providing efficient, secure, reasonably priced, and culturally sensitive healthcare services will be highlighted on World Health Day in 2024.
Universal Health Coverage: Ensuring everyone has access to healthcare when needed without worrying about paying for it is known as universal health coverage.
Empowering Individuals: This subject emphasises the importance of access to knowledge and education. Well-informed and empowered people may make choices that are best for their health and well-being.

Creating Equal Health Systems: This topic promotes dealing with the underlying causes of inequities in health. It supports programs and policies that advance equitable access to socioeconomic determinants of health, treatment, and preventative care.
subpara: The underlying idea that each person has the right to obtain high-quality healthcare and make educated decisions about their health is emphasised by the World Health Day 2024 theme. It reiterates the commitment to universal health coverage and the fulfilment of health as a fundamental human right for everyone by emphasising the inextricable link between health and human rights.

paragraphs: Why Do We Celebrate World Health Day?

In honour of the World Health Organization's (WHO) foundation, people celebrate World Health Day. It offers a rare chance to gather support for particular global health challenges and bring significant attention to pertinent areas of global health. The following are some strong arguments in favour of World Health Day's importance to world health:
list: People are ignorant of the risks and protective measures associated with many serious health diseases, which cause them to go unnoticed. World Health Day 2024 brings these issues to light, encouraging discussion and action.
World Health Day emphasises that everyone has the fundamental human right to health, regardless of where they live, their financial situation, or their past.

World Health Day allows governments to allocate funds to healthcare infrastructure and resources, encourages people to adopt a healthy lifestyle, and allows healthcare organisations to consistently enhance the services they provide.
As a reminder that attaining global health necessitates a concerted effort, World Health Day promotes cooperation between governments, non-governmental organisations, and healthcare professionals.

World Health Day offers a forum for celebrating developments in preventative medicine and modern healthcare. Showcasing effective tactics and inventions might encourage more research and dedication to enhancing global health results.

sections.heading: History and Importance of World Health Day
paragraphs: World Health Day originated with the foundation of the World Health Organization. The World Health Organization (WHO) is a United Nations organisation that addresses public health issues worldwide. World Health Day, founded in 1950, is a significant occasion that features a different theme every year to draw attention to global health concerns. On this day, health-related events at the local, national, and international levels are coordinated by the 194 member nations that comprise the World Health Organization (WHO).

The potential of World Health Day to inspire action and build momentum for health projects at the local, national, and international levels is what makes it so significant. It offers an opportunity to bring attention to new health risks, promote legal modifications, and gather resources for urgent medical problems. In addition, World Health Day serves as a reminder of how closely related health is to other facets of human progress, such as economic growth, poverty reduction, and education. The eradication of diseases, the decrease in maternal and infant mortality, and the advancement of mental health and well-being are just a few of the critical health-related goals that World Health Day has helped to advance throughout the years.

sections.subheading: Common Health Issues Addressed on World Health Day
paragraphs: In addition to other health-related concerns, World Health Day 2024 offers a forum for discussing the following:
list: Access to Healthcare: Reducing gaps in healthcare access and advocating for universal health coverage to guarantee that no one is denied necessary medical care due to insufficient funds.
Infectious diseases: Handling new infectious threats like COVID-19 as well as the protection, treatment, and control of infectious diseases, including HIV/AIDS, TB, and malaria.

Maternal and child health: Promoting mother and child health by means of programs designed to lower maternal death rates, increase access to antenatal and neonatal care, and guarantee vaccination rates.
Mental health awareness: Promoting increased access to mental health services and assistance, lowering stigma associated with mental health conditions, and increasing knowledge of these issues.

Non-communicable diseases: Using preventive, early detection, and innovative technologies in healthcare to address the rising burden of non-communicable diseases (NCDs), including diabetes, cancer, cardiovascular disease, and respiratory ailments.
Health equity: Promoting fair access to medical treatment and resolving inequalities in health that arise from factors such as geography, gender, ethnicity, and class.
Environmental health: Highlighting how environmental elements affect health, encouraging environmentally friendly behaviour, and reducing risks to the environment.

sections.subheading: How to Celebrate World Health Day
paragraphs: There are many ways to observe World Health Day to support healthy living and raise awareness on health. Here are a few recommendations:
list: Local communities can host health education and screening programs to increase the public's understanding of prevalent health conditions and give access to preventative services.
Organising webinars, workshops, and seminars on subjects like stress management, mental health, physical exercise, nutrition, and healthy living.
Launching social media initiatives to highlight success stories, promote health habits, and distribute health-related information.
Putting health promotion concepts and programs into action in partnership with businesses, schools, and community groups.

Engaging decision-makers and promoting laws that promote disease prevention and health promotion, such as taxes on unhealthy foods, tobacco advertising prohibitions, and funding for public health facilities.

It is impossible to overestimate the significance of World Health Day 2024, which may be utilised to plan fundraising activities in support of nearby free clinics and other public health services. Take part in a walk or run to raise money and awareness on health, or give something personal to a worthy organisation that supports world health.

sections.subheading: An Empowered and Equitable Healthcare Future
paragraphs: The theme of World Health Day 2024, "My Health, My Right," serves as a reminder of our shared obligation to make sure that everyone has access to the healthcare they require and deserve. As we work toward a healthier, more just world, we at Omni Hospitals are steadfast in our commitment to promoting health equality, empowering people, and bringing about significant change. We work to build a future where health is genuinely a universal right, not a privilege afforded to a select few, via outreach, education, advocacy, and innovation.
